sentence: The book was a bit jejune and boring, so I decided to read an adventure story instead.
origin: Latin jejunus empty of food, hungry, meager

definition: a monetary subunit of the won (South Korea)
sentence: For a snack, we had Korean jeon, which are savory pancakes made with vegetables or seafood.

definition: to get rid of as superfluous or encumbering : omit or forgo as part of a plan or as the result of some other decision
sentence: The pilot had to jettison some of the extra weight from the plane to make a safe landing.

definition: an edible starchy tuberous root of a tropical American vine (Pachyrhizus erosus) of the legume family that is eaten raw or cooked
sentence: Jicama is a crunchy, white root vegetable that tastes great when it is sliced into sticks.
origin: Mexican Spanish jícama, from Nahuatl xīcamatl

definition: underhanded manipulation or dealings : trickery
sentence: The detective suspected some jiggery-pokery was going on when the jewels went missing.
origin: probably alteration of Scots joukery-pawkery, from jouk to dodge, cheat + pawk trick, wile

definition: having a protruding lower jaw.
sentence: The bulldog looked very funny with its jimberjawed face and sticking-out bottom teeth.

definition: extreme chauvinism or nationalism marked especially by a belligerent foreign policy
sentence: The politician’s speech was full of jingoism, suggesting his country was better than all others.

definition: an unlicensed taxicab
sentence: A jitney is a small bus or car that carries passengers along a regular route for a small fee.

definition: said or done as a joke : characterized by jesting : playful
sentence: The room was filled with jocularity as all the children laughed at the clown's silly tricks.
origin: borrowed from Latin joculāris "laughable, facetious," from joculus "joke, jest" (diminutive of jocus "jest") + -āris

definition: keen or buoyant enjoyment of life
sentence: The happy baker had a real joie de vivre and sang while he made his delicious bread.

definition: a day's journey; a long stretch of arid land to be crossed in one day.
sentence: The travelers prepared for a long jornada across the dry and dusty desert.

definition: having, exercising, or characterized by sound judgment
sentence: It is judicious to save some of your allowance each week instead of spending it all at once.
origin: borrowed from Middle French judicieux, from Latin jūdicium "legal proceedings, court, judgment, faculty of judging, discernment" + Middle French -eux, going back to Old French -eus, earlier -os, -ous, going back to Latin -ōsus

definition: a preparation or garnish of food that has been cut into thin strips
sentence: The chef showed us how to julienne the carrots into thin, matchstick-sized pieces.
origin: French, short for potage à la julienne, probably from Julienne woman's name

definition: the heroine of Shakespeare's tragedy Romeo and Juliet who dies for love of Romeo
sentence: A juliet sleeve is a type of sleeve that is puffy at the top and tight at the bottom.

definition: of, relating to, or being the period of the Mesozoic era between the Triassic and the Cretaceous or the corresponding system of rocks marked by the presence of dinosaurs and the first appearance of birds
sentence: The Stegosaurus lived during the Jurassic period, millions of years before humans existed.
origin: French jurassique, from Jura mountain range

definition: compositions produced in the artist's or author's youth
sentence: The museum displayed the juvenilia of the famous author, showing the stories she wrote as a child.

definition: the Brazil nut tree or its seed.
sentence: A juvia is another name for a Brazil nut, which grows inside a large, woody pod.

definition: to place (different things) side by side (as to compare them or contrast them or to create an interesting effect)
sentence: The artist decided to juxtapose the bright yellow flowers against a dark blue background.

definition: emperor; especially : the ruler of Germany from 1871 to 1918
sentence: For lunch, I had a ham and cheese sandwich on a soft kaiser roll.
origin: Middle English, from Old Norse keisari; akin to Old High German keisur emperor; both from a prehistoric Germanic word borrowed from Latin Caesar, cognomen of the Emperor Augustus

definition: just-in-time
sentence: Our teacher uses a kanban board with sticky notes to show us which classroom chores are done and which are left to do.
origin: Japanese, sign, placard; from the cards used on assembly lines to signal that parts are needed

definition: a Japanese system of writing that utilizes characters borrowed or adapted from Chinese writing; also : a single character in the kanji system
sentence: In our world cultures class, we learned that kanji are symbols used in Japanese writing that represent whole words or ideas.

definition: a device that plays instrumental accompaniments for a selection of songs to which the user sings along and that records the user's singing with the music; also : a form of entertainment involving the use of such a device (as in a bar)
sentence: For my birthday party, we all took turns singing our favorite songs on the karaoke machine.
origin: Japanese, from kara empty + ōke, short for ōkesutora orchestra

definition: an irregular limestone region with sinkholes, underground streams, and caverns
sentence: The guide showed us the karst landscape, where the water had carved deep caves and sinkholes into the limestone rock.
origin: German, from Slovene dialect or Croatian dialect kras, kars, type of rock, region composed of such rock

definition: living in or relating to clean water or environments free of organic pollution.
sentence: The scientist tested the lake to make sure the water was katharobic, meaning it was clean and full of life-giving oxygen.

definition: a Japanese dish consisting of a breaded, deep-fried cutlet of meat.
sentence: I ate a delicious piece of chicken katsu, which is a crispy, breaded cutlet served with a savory sauce.

definition: a square of cloth used as a head covering or worn as a scarf around the neck
sentence: Grandma tied a colorful silk kerchief around her neck to keep the chilly wind away.
origin: Middle English courchef, from Anglo-French coverchef, cuerchief, from coverir to cover + chef head

definition: county in the eastern Ireland province of Leinster; capital Naas area 654 square miles (1700 square kilometers), population 210,312
sentence: My pen pal lives in County Kildare, a beautiful place in Ireland famous for its green fields and horses.

definition: the study of the principles of mechanics and anatomy in relation to human movement
sentence: The gym teacher studied kinesiology to learn exactly how the human body moves during exercise.

definition: a large, bright-colored flycatcher common in the Americas, named for its call.
sentence: We heard the loud, cheerful call of the kiskadee bird sitting on a branch in the garden.

definition: an isolated block of rock that is the remnant of a larger overthrust sheet.
sentence: Geologists study a klippe to see how a piece of old rock ended up on top of much younger land.

definition: a long Japanese zither having 13 strings
sentence: The musician played a beautiful song on the koto, a long Japanese instrument with many strings.

definition: island and volcano 2667 feet (813 meters) high in the Sunda Strait between Sumatra and Java, Indonesia
sentence: We read about the massive volcanic eruption of Krakatoa that happened a long time ago in Indonesia.

definition: the thick, creamy head of foam that develops on top of fermenting beer.
sentence: The baker explained that krausen is the foamy head that forms on top of a liquid while it is fermenting.

definition: a colorless relatively inert gaseous element found in air in trace amounts and used especially in electric lamps
sentence: Krypton is a colorless gas that is used inside some high-powered light bulbs to make them shine brightly.

definition: a close-fitting brimless cylindrical or round hat
sentence: For the celebration, Omar wore a beautifully embroidered kufi cap on his head.

definition: a baked pudding (as of potatoes or noodles) usually served as a side dish
sentence: My aunt brought a sweet noodle kugel to our family dinner, and it was the best side dish on the table.
origin: Yiddish kugl, from Middle High German kugel ball

definition: being stir-fried or sometimes deep-fried and served in a spicy hot sauce usually with peanuts
sentence: My dad ordered kung pao chicken, but it was a little too spicy for me because of the red peppers.
origin: borrowed from Chinese (Beijing) gōng bǎo "palace guardian" in the name of such dishes (as gōng bǎo jī dīng "kung pao diced chicken")

definition: of or relating to the wrasse family of fishes.
sentence: The colorful wrasse is a type of labroid fish that lives among the coral reefs in the ocean.

definition: of, relating to, or resembling a labyrinth : intricate, involved
sentence: The old castle had labyrinthine hallways that were so twisty we almost got lost looking for the exit.

definition: using or involving the use of a minimum of words : concise to the point of seeming rude or mysterious
sentence: The cowboy was very laconic and only answered questions with a simple 'yep' or 'nope.'
origin: Latin laconicus Spartan, from Greek lakōnikos; from the Spartan reputation for terseness of speech

definition: of, relating to, formed in, living in, or growing in lakes
sentence: Scientists study lacustrine deposits to find out what kind of plants lived near the lake thousands of years ago.
origin: French or Italian lacustre, from Latin lacus lake

definition: a system of shifting cultivation used in Southeast Asia.
sentence: In some tropical areas, farmers use ladang, which means they clear a small patch of forest to grow their crops.

definition: the people of a religious faith as distinguished from its clergy
sentence: The church leaders gave a special presentation to the laity, who are the regular members of the congregation.

definition: playing lightly on or over a surface : flickering
sentence: The firelight flickered lambently across the walls of the cozy cabin.
origin: Latin lambent-, lambens, present participle of lambere to lick

definition: a very young lamb; used as a term of endearment for a small child.
sentence: The tiny, fluffy lambkin stayed close to its mother while it learned to walk in the meadow.

definition: relating to a system of instruction in which advanced pupils teach those below them.
sentence: The museum showed us a Lancasterian classroom where older students helped teach the younger ones.

definition: producing or tending to produce languor
sentence: On the hot summer afternoon, the cat felt languorous and didn't want to do anything but nap in the shade.

definition: treated or prepared with lanolin (wool grease).
sentence: The soap was lanolated, which made my hands feel very soft and smooth after washing them.

definition: any of a genus (Lantana) of tropical shrubs or perennial herbs of the vervain family with showy heads of small bright flowers
sentence: We planted lantana in the garden because its bright clusters of flowers attract so many butterflies.
origin: New Latin, from Italian dialect, viburnum

definition: the unlawful taking of personal property with intent to deprive the rightful owner of it permanently
sentence: The sneaky raccoon committed a bit of larceny when it stole the campers' bag of marshmallows.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French larecin theft, from Latin latrocinium robbery, from latron-, latro mercenary soldier, probably from Greek *latrōn, from latron pay

definition: liberal giving (as of money) to or as if to an inferior; also : something so given
sentence: The community was very thankful for the largesses of the local business owners who donated toys for the holiday.
origin: Middle English largesse, from Anglo-French, from large

definition: a small closed casket, box, or chest often used as a container for human remains in ancient Greece.
sentence: In the ancient history museum, we saw a stone larnax that was used long ago to hold important items.

definition: a condition of weariness or debility : fatigue
sentence: After the long five-mile hike, a feeling of lassitude came over me and I fell asleep on the car ride home.
origin: Middle English, from Latin lassitudo, from lassus weary; probably akin to Old English læt late

definition: a large landed estate, especially in Italy, owned by an absentee landlord.
sentence: A latifondo is a very large farm or estate that was common in Italy many years ago.

definition: a long strap on a saddletree of a western saddle to adjust the cinch
sentence: The cowboy used a leather latigo strap to tighten the saddle on his horse before the race.

definition: of, relating to, or expressing praise
sentence: The teacher gave me a laudatory note on my essay, praising how hard I worked on the research.

definition: a Mediterranean mint (Lavandula angustifolia synonym L. officinalis) widely cultivated for its narrow aromatic leaves and spikes of lilac-purple flowers which are dried and used in sachets and from which is extracted an aromatic oil used chiefly in perfumery
sentence: I love the smell of the purple lavender flowers growing in the pots on our porch.
origin: Middle English lavendre, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin lavandula

definition: suspicious, wary —often used with of
sentence: The squirrel was leery of the cat and waited until it went inside before running across the yard.

definition: the specialized language of the legal profession
sentence: The contract was full of difficult legalese that made it hard for me to understand the rules of the game.

definition: in a manner that is smooth and connected (as between successive tones) —used especially as a direction in music
sentence: The music teacher told me to play the notes legato, so they would sound smooth and connected.

definition: alert facile quickness of mind or body
sentence: The gymnast moved with amazing legerity, flipping through the air and landing perfectly on her feet.
origin: Middle French legereté, from Old French, lightness, from leger light, from Vulgar Latin *leviarius, from Latin levis

definition: a band of fibers and especially nerve fibers
sentence: In science class, we learned that a lemniscus is a bundle of nerves in the brain that carries information.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, ribbon, from Greek lēmniskos

definition: the garden dormouse of Europe.
sentence: The lerot is a small, cute garden dormouse with a black mask around its eyes.

definition: a sea monster defeated by Yahweh in various scriptural accounts
sentence: In the old story, the sailors were afraid of a leviathan, which was a giant and powerful sea monster.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin, from Hebrew liwyāthān

definition: to establish liaison
sentence: The class president had to liaise between the students and the principal to plan the school dance.

definition: a crystalline compound C14H22N2O that is used in the form of its hydrochloride as a local anesthetic and as an antiarrhythmic agent
sentence: The dentist used a little bit of lidocaine to numb my gum before he started working on my tooth.

definition: to draw or paint on a surface
sentence: The sunset was so bright that the clouds were limned with a beautiful golden light.
origin: Middle English limnen to illuminate (a manuscript), probably back-formation from lymnour illuminator, alteration of lumenur, from Anglo-French aluminer, enluminer to illuminate, ultimately from Latin illuminare

definition: rye bread made with molasses or brown sugar
sentence: For breakfast, we had a slice of Swedish limpa bread, which has a sweet taste of orange and rye.

definition: a marine gastropod mollusk (especially families Acmaeidae and Patellidae) that has a low conical shell broadly open beneath, browses over rocks or timbers in the littoral area, and clings very tightly when disturbed
sentence: While exploring the tide pools, we found a limpet sticking very tightly to the side of a rock.
origin: Middle English lempet, from Old English lempedu, from Medieval Latin lampreda lamprey

definition: marked by transparency : pellucid
sentence: The water in the mountain stream was so limpid that we could see every pebble on the bottom.
origin: French or Latin; French limpide, from Latin limpidus, perhaps from lympha water

definition: a large brown wading bird (Aramus guarauna) of southern Georgia, Florida, and Central and South America that resembles a bittern but has a longer slightly curved bill, longer neck and legs, and white stripes on head and neck
sentence: The limpkin is a long-legged bird that lives in swamps and uses its beak to eat snails.

definition: a common language consisting of Italian mixed with French, Spanish, Greek, and Arabic that was formerly spoken in Mediterranean ports
sentence: Since everyone spoke different languages, they used English as a lingua franca so they could talk to each other.

definition: a common small brownish Old World finch (Linaria cannabina) of which the male has red on the breast and crown during breeding season
sentence: A linnet is a small, brown songbird that likes to build its nest in thick bushes.
origin: Middle French linette, from lin flax, from Latin linum; from its feeding on flax seeds

definition: a staff having a pointed foot (as for sticking into the ground) and a forked tip and formerly used to hold a lighted match for firing cannon
sentence: In the history museum, we saw a linstock, which was a long pole used to light a cannon from a safe distance.
origin: Dutch lontstok, from lont match + stok stick

definition: letter for letter
sentence: I copied the secret code literatim, making sure every single letter was exactly the same as the original.

definition: a chemical element of the alkali metal group that is the lightest metal known and that is used especially in alloys and glass, in mechanical lubricants, and in storage batteries
sentence: Lithium is a lightweight metal that is used to make the batteries inside many cell phones and laptops.
origin: borrowed from New Latin (in German context) Lithium, taken as the metallic component of the alkali Lithion, probably based on Greek litheîon, neuter of litheîos "of stone," derivative of líthos "stone, rock," of obscure origin

definition: a musical instrument consisting of a series of resonant stone slabs.
sentence: We saw a musical instrument called a lithophone, which is made of flat stones that make a ringing sound when hit.

definition: a coloring matter from lichens that turns red in acid solutions and blue in alkaline solutions and is used as an acid-base indicator
sentence: In science, we used litmus paper to see if the lemon juice was an acid by watching it turn red.
origin: Middle English litmose, of Scandinavian origin; akin to Old Norse litmosi herbs used in dyeing, from litr color (akin to Old English wlite brightness, appearance) + mosi moss; akin to Old English mōs moss

definition: surgical removal of a lobe of an organ (such as a lung) or gland (such as the thyroid)
sentence: The doctor had to perform a lobectomy to remove a small part of the patient's lung so they could get better.

definition: surgical severance of nerve fibers connecting the frontal lobes to the thalamus that has been performed especially formerly chiefly to treat mental illness
sentence: A long time ago, doctors used a lobotomy to treat brain problems, but they don't do that anymore.

definition: one who eats foods grown locally whenever possible
sentence: My mom is a locavore because she tries to only buy food that is grown by farmers near our town.

definition: lake
sentence: We visited Loch Ness in Scotland to see if we could find the famous monster hiding in the deep lake.
origin: Middle English (Scots) louch, from Scottish Gaelic loch; akin to Latin lacus lake

definition: of, relating to, or marked by the use of logographs : consisting of logographs
sentence: The ancient Egyptians used a logographic writing system where one picture represented a whole word.

definition: angular distance measured on a great circle of reference from the intersection of the adopted zero meridian with this reference circle to the similar intersection of the meridian passing through the object
sentence: On the map, the lines of longitude run up and down to show how far east or west a place is.
origin: Middle English, from Latin longitudin-, longitudo, from longus

definition: any of numerous small arboreal chiefly Australasian parrots (family Loriidae) that usually have long slender tongue papillae which form an organ resembling a brush
sentence: The lorikeet is a very colorful parrot that uses its fuzzy tongue to drink nectar from flowers.

definition: involving or causing some loss of data
sentence: When you shrink a photo too much, it uses a lossy method that makes the picture look a little blurry.

definition: a substance used to kill lice.
sentence: The nurse recommended a special lousicide shampoo to get rid of the itchy bugs in the boy's hair.

definition: a tall ceramic vessel used in ancient Greek marriage and funeral rites.
sentence: The museum had a loutrophoros, a tall Greek vase that was used in wedding ceremonies a long time ago.

definition: any of several aromatic perennial herbs of the carrot family; especially : a European herb (Levisticum officinale) sometimes cultivated for use in medicine especially as a diuretic and in cookery usually as a flavoring agent
sentence: My dad grew lovage in the herb garden, and it smells just like celery.
origin: Middle English lovache, from Anglo-French luvasche, lovasche, from Late Latin levisticum, alteration of Latin ligusticum, from neuter of ligusticus Ligurian, from Ligur-, Ligus, noun, Ligurian

definition: clear in thought or expression : lucid
sentence: The teacher gave such a luculent explanation of the math problem that everyone understood it right away.
origin: borrowed from Late Latin lūculentus, going back to Latin, "splendid, excellent, fine," from lūc-, lūx "light" + -ulentus

definition: amusing or laughable through obvious absurdity, incongruity, exaggeration, or eccentricity
sentence: It would be ludicrous to try and fit a giant elephant inside a tiny toy car.
origin: Latin ludicrus, from ludus play, sport; perhaps akin to Greek loidoros abusive

definition: the cavity of a tubular organ or part
sentence: A lumen is a unit that measures how much light a bulb puts out; a brighter bulb has more lumens.
origin: borrowed from Latin lūmin-, lūmen "light, source of light, opening to let in light, aperture of any kind," going back to *lou̯k-s-men, earlier *leu̯k-s-men, from Indo-European *leu̯k- "become bright" + a concretizing suffix *-s-men

definition: one who makes stringed musical instruments (such as violins or guitars)
sentence: A luthier is a skilled person who knows how to build and repair guitars and violins.
origin: French, from luth lute (from Middle French lut)

definition: of, relating to, or resembling an otter.
sentence: The way the otter slid down the muddy bank into the river was very lutrine, or otter-like.

definition: to grow profusely : thrive
sentence: After the cold hike, I wanted to luxuriate in a warm bubble bath for an hour.
origin: Latin luxuriatus, past participle of luxuriare, from luxuria

definition: macadamized roadway or pavement especially with a bituminous binder
sentence: The workers used macadam, which is a mix of small stones, to pave the new road.
origin: after John Loudon McAdam †1836 Scottish civil engineer who introduced this method of road construction

definition: a hard-shelled nut of an Australian evergreen tree (genus Macadamia, especially M. integrifolia or M. tetraphylla) of the protea family that somewhat resembles the filbert and is cultivated extensively in Hawaii —called also macadamia
sentence: I love eating cookies that have white chocolate chips and crunchy macadamia nuts.
origin: borrowed from New Latin Macadamia, genus name, from John Macadam †1865 Scottish-born Australian chemist + New Latin -ia

definition: an opening between the corbels of a projecting parapet or in the floor of a gallery or roof of a portal for discharging missiles upon assailants below
sentence: The castle had a machicolation, which is an opening in the wall used to drop things on attackers below.
origin: Medieval Latin machicolare to furnish with machicolations, from Middle French machicoller, from machicoleis machicolation, from macher to crush + col neck, from Latin collum

definition: an act of machinating
sentence: The villain’s latest machination was a secret plan to take over the whole city.

definition: a twin crystal
sentence: The crystal collector found a macle, which is a special twin crystal that grew together in a unique way.
origin: French, wide-meshed net, lozenge voided, macle, from Old French, mesh, lozenge voided, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German masca mesh

definition: a genus of trees that includes the Osage orange.
sentence: The maclura tree, also known as the Osage orange, grows bumpy green fruits that look like brains.

definition: spot, blotch; especially : macule
sentence: The doctor used a special light to check the macular part of my eye to make sure I could see clearly.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Latin, "stain, spot, blemish, one of the interstices of a net," of uncertain origin

definition: a Eurasian herb (Rubia tinctorum of the family Rubiaceae, the madder family) with whorled leaves and small yellowish panicled flowers succeeded by dark berries; broadly : any of several related herbs (genus Rubia)
sentence: Long ago, people used the roots of the madder plant to dye their clothes a bright red color.
origin: Middle English, from Old English mædere; akin to Old High German matara madder

definition: marked by poor or inadequate adaptation
sentence: Biting your nails when you are nervous is a maladaptive habit that doesn't really help the problem.

definition: a disease or disorder of the animal body
sentence: The kind doctor worked hard to find a cure for the strange malady that made the prince feel weak.
origin: Middle English maladie, from Anglo-French, from malade sick, from Latin male habitus in bad condition

definition: the usually unintentionally humorous misuse or distortion of a word or phrase; especially : the use of a word sounding somewhat like the one intended but ludicrously wrong in the context
sentence: It was a funny malapropism when the boy said 'Texas' instead of 'taxes' by mistake.
origin: Mrs. Malaprop, character noted for her misuse of words in R. B. Sheridan's comedy The Rivals (1775)

definition: having, showing, or coming from intense often vicious ill will, spite, or hatred
sentence: In the story, the malevolent witch tried to stop the heroes from reaching the castle.
origin: Latin malevolent-, malevolens, from male badly + volent-, volens, present participle of velle to wish ,

definition: wrongdoing or misconduct especially by a public official
sentence: The mayor was in trouble for malfeasance because he used the city's money for his own vacation.

definition: to pretend or exaggerate incapacity or illness (as to avoid duty or work)
sentence: Even though he felt fine, the boy tried to malinger so he wouldn't have to take the math test.

definition: city in northwestern England east-northeast of Liverpool made accessible to the Irish Sea by way of the Manchester Ship Canal, which stretches 35 miles (56 kilometers) to the estuary of the Mersey River population 503,000
sentence: A person who is born in the city of Manchester, England, is called a Mancunian.

definition: in direct competition or conflict especially between two people
sentence: The two wrestlers competed mano a mano to see who was the strongest in the ring.

definition: to release from slavery
sentence: In history, we learned that a leader might manumit a person to give them their freedom.
origin: Middle English manumitten, from Anglo-French manumettre, from Latin manumittere, from manus hand + mittere to let go, send

definition: a female horse or other equine animal especially when fully mature or of breeding age
sentence: The gentle mare stood in the field and watched her young foal run through the grass.
origin: Middle English, from Old English mere; akin to Old High German merha mare, Old English mearh horse, Welsh march

definition: marginal notes or embellishments (as in a book)
sentence: I found an old book that was full of marginalia, which are notes written in the edges of the pages.
origin: New Latin, from Medieval Latin, neuter plural of marginalis

definition: a xylophone of southern Africa and Central America with resonators beneath each bar; also : a modern form of this instrument
sentence: The musician used wooden mallets to play a cheerful tune on the large marimba.
origin: of Bantu origin; akin to Kimbundu marimba xylophone

definition: to ruin or diminish the perfection or wholeness of : spoil
sentence: Be careful not to drop the heavy box, or you might end up marring the beautiful wood floor.
origin: Middle English marren, from Old English mierran to obstruct, waste; akin to Old High German merren to obstruct

definition: any of an order (Marsupialia) of mammals comprising kangaroos, wombats, bandicoots, opossums, and related animals that do not develop a true placenta and that usually have a pouch on the abdomen of the female which covers the teats and serves to carry the young
sentence: A kangaroo is a famous marsupial that carries its baby in a pouch on its tummy.
origin: from the base of New Latin Marsupialia, order name, from neuter plural of marsūpiālis "of a pouch," from marsūpium "pouch, " + -ālis

definition: the suffering of death on account of adherence to a cause and especially to one's religious faith
sentence: The statue was built to honor the martyrdom of the brave hero who gave up everything for his town.

definition: any of various extinct mammals (genus Mammut synonym Mastodon) of the elephant family existing from the Miocene through the Pleistocene that are distinguished from the related mammoths chiefly by molar teeth with cone-shaped cusps
sentence: The museum had a giant skeleton of a mastodon, an ancient relative of the elephant with long tusks.
origin: borrowed from New Latin Mastodont-, Mastodon, genus name, Latinization of French mastodonte, vernacular name for the animal, from Greek mastós "breast, nipple" (probably from a pre-Greek substratal language) + French -odonte ; so named from the nipple-like cusps on the crowns of the molar teeth

definition: the action or process or matriculating (that is, enrolling) or the state of being matriculated (as at a college or university)
sentence: The university held a ceremony for the matriculation of all the new students starting school.

definition: a large brownish edible Japanese mushroom (Tricholoma matsutake) having firm flesh and a spicy aroma; also : a large whitish mushroom (Tricholoma magnivelere synonym Armillaria ponderosa) of northern North America that is similar to the Japanese matsutake
sentence: In some countries, the matsutake mushroom is a very expensive treat that smells like spicy pine.
origin: Japanese matsu-take, matsudake, from matsu pine tree + take mushroom

definition: lacking flavor or having an unpleasant taste
sentence: The movie was a bit too mawkish for me because everyone was crying over every little thing.
origin: Middle English mawke maggot, probably from Old Norse mathkr

definition: a formal acknowledgment of personal fault or error
sentence: When I accidentally broke the vase, I said 'mea culpa' to show I knew it was my fault.

definition: a place regarded as a center for a specified group, activity, or interest
sentence: The big toy store is a mecca for kids who love building with blocks and racing toy cars.
origin: Mecca, Saudi Arabia, a destination of pilgrims in the Islamic world

definition: the quality or state of being mediocre
sentence: The coach told us not to settle for mediocrity and to always try our absolute best.
origin: Middle English mediokerte, mediocrite "moderation, medium size or amount," borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French mediocrité "intermediate state," borrowed from Latin mediocritāt-, mediocritās "moderateness of size or amount, intermediate character, limited ability," from mediocris "of medium size, moderate, " + -itāt-, -itās

definition: a mortal Gorgon who is slain when decapitated by Perseus
sentence: In science class, we learned that a medusa is the stage of a jellyfish where it looks like a floating umbrella.

definition: a mania for great or grandiose performance
sentence: The villain in the cartoon was a megalomaniac who thought he should rule the whole world.
origin: + , after German Megalomanie or French mégalomanie

definition: a white crystalline organic base C3H6N6 with a high melting point that is used especially in melamine resins
sentence: Our colorful picnic plates are made of melamine, which is a type of hard plastic that doesn't break easily.

definition: a mixture or medley of heterogeneous elements.
sentence: The bowl was filled with a mélange of colorful fruit, including grapes, apples, and berries.

definition: a confused struggle; especially : a hand-to-hand fight among several people
sentence: A small melee broke out in the yard when all the puppies tried to grab the same tennis ball.
origin: French mêlée, from Old French meslee, from mesler to mix

definition: a group of notes or tones sung on one syllable in plainsong
sentence: The singer performed a melismatic song, stretching one single word over many different notes.
origin: New Latin, from Greek, song, melody, from melizein to sing, from melos song

definition: given to or characterized by deception or falsehood or divergence from absolute truth
sentence: The fox in the fable was very mendacious and told many lies to trick the other animals.

definition: mendicancy
sentence: The book described a time of mendicity when many poor people had to ask for food on the streets.
origin: Middle English mendicite, from Middle French mendicité, from Latin mendicitat-, mendicitas, from mendicus

definition: inflammation of the meninges and especially of the pia mater and arachnoid; specifically : a disease marked by inflammation of the meninges that is either a relatively mild illness caused by a virus (such as various Coxsackieviruses) or a more severe usually life-threatening illness caused by a bacterium (especially the meningococcus, Neisseria meningitides, or the serotype designated B of Haemophilus influenzae)
sentence: The doctor checked the boy for meningitis to make sure the lining of his brain was healthy.

definition: a member of any of various Protestant groups derived from the Anabaptist movement in Holland and characterized by congregational autonomy and rejection of military service
sentence: The Mennonites are a group of people known for living simple lives and helping their neighbors.

definition: of, relating to, or resembling mephitis : foul-smelling
sentence: We stayed away from the swamp because of the mephitic smell of the muddy water.

definition: any of various fish-eating diving ducks (especially genus Mergus) with a slender bill hooked at the end and serrated along the margins and usually a crested head
sentence: The merganser is a type of duck with a thin, serrated beak that helps it catch fish.
origin: New Latin, from Latin mergus, a waterfowl (from mergere) + anser goose

definition: a great circle on the surface of the earth passing through the poles
sentence: The Prime Meridian is the starting line that scientists use to measure time around the world.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French meridien, from meridien of noon, from Latin meridianus, from meridies noon, south, irregular from medius mid + dies day ,

definition: any of a breed of fine-wooled white sheep originating in Spain and producing a heavy fleece of exceptional quality
sentence: I wore a soft sweater made from merino wool to stay warm on the chilly winter day.

definition: middle, median
sentence: The dentist checked the mesial surface of the tooth, which is the side facing the front of the mouth.

definition: region of southwestern Asia between the Tigris and the Euphrates rivers extending from the mountains of eastern Asia Minor to the Persian Gulf
sentence: The Mesopotamian people were some of the first in history to invent writing and farming.

definition: in a metaphorical or figurative sense rather than a literal sense : by using a metaphor
sentence: When I say I am 'feeling blue,' I am speaking metaphorically because I'm not actually that color.

definition: transformation of one tissue into another
sentence: The scientist studied metaplasia, which is when one type of body cell changes into a different type.

definition: to spread or grow by or as if by metastasis
sentence: Doctors work quickly to stop a sickness before it can metastasize and spread to other parts of the body.

definition: of, relating to, or being the part of the human foot or of the hind foot in quadrupeds between the tarsus and the phalanges that in humans comprises five elongated bones which form the front of the instep and ball of the foot
sentence: If you drop a heavy rock on your foot, you might hurt a metatarsal bone.

definition: September 29 celebrated as the feast of St. Michael the Archangel
sentence: Michaelmas is a traditional holiday celebrated in autumn to mark the end of the harvest.
origin: Middle English mychelmesse, from Old English Michaeles mæsse Michael's mass

definition: a dress, skirt, or coat that usually extends to the mid-calf
sentence: My electronic keyboard uses MIDI to send the music I play directly into the computer.

definition: of or relating to a millennium
sentence: A millennial is a person who was born between the early 1980s and the late 1990s.

definition: any of various small-seeded annual cereal and forage grasses:
sentence: We put out a bird feeder filled with millet, which is a tiny grain that small birds love to eat.
origin: Middle English milet, from Middle French, from Old French, diminutive of mil, from Latin milium; akin to Greek melinē millet

definition: one thousandth of a second
sentence: A millisecond is a very tiny unit of time; there are one thousand of them in just one second.

definition: an Argentine ballroom dance resembling the tango; also a place where people go to dance.
sentence: We watched dancers perform a milonga, which is a fast and exciting dance from South America.

definition: a timid, meek, or unassertive person
sentence: The main character was a milquetoast person who was too shy to ever speak up for himself.
origin: Caspar Milquetoast, comic strip character created by H. T. Webster †1952 American cartoonist

definition: menacing or threatening in character.
sentence: The dark, minacious clouds in the sky made us think a big thunderstorm was coming.

definition: an Italian soup, typically containing vegetables and pasta.
sentence: My grandmother cooked a big pot of minestra, a thick vegetable soup with beans and pasta.

definition: a type of igneous rock containing biotite; also a high-grade iron ore of Lorraine.
sentence: Geologists found a piece of minette, which is a type of dark rock that forms underground.

definition: very small
sentence: The ants looked minuscule compared to the giant crumbs they were trying to carry.
origin: borrowed from French & New Latin; French, "lower case (of a letter)," borrowed from New Latin minusculus, going back to Latin, "somewhat smaller, fairly small," from the base of minor, minus "smaller" (comparative of parvus "small") + -culus, diminutive suffix

definition: of, relating to, or being the legal rights of an arrested person to have an attorney, to have an attorney appointed if indigent, and to remain silent so as to avoid self-incrimination
sentence: The police must read the Miranda rights to a person to explain that they have the right to stay silent.
origin: from Miranda v. Arizona, the U.S. Supreme Court ruling establishing such rights

definition: the misnaming of a person in a legal instrument
sentence: Calling a koala a 'bear' is a misnomer because it is actually a marsupial.
origin: Middle English misnoumer, from Anglo-French mesnomer, from mes- mis- + nomer to name, from Latin nominare

definition: to cause to become less harsh or hostile : mollify
sentence: Wearing a helmet is a mitigative step that helps protect your head if you fall off your bike.
origin: Middle English, from Latin mitigatus, past participle of mitigare to soften, from mitis soft + -igare (akin to Latin agere to drive); akin to Old Irish moíth soft

definition: a species of goatfish found in the Pacific Ocean.
sentence: The moano is a colorful goatfish found in the ocean near Hawaii that has stripes on its tail.

definition: a doughlike mass made from cooked and pounded glutinous rice used in Japan as an unbaked pastry
sentence: For dessert, we had mochi, which are sweet, chewy rice cakes filled with ice cream.

definition: a rare, naturally occurring mineral (silicon carbide) often used as a diamond substitute.
sentence: The ring had a moissanite stone that sparkled almost as brightly as a real diamond.

definition: to soothe in temper or disposition : appease
sentence: The mother tried to mollify her crying baby by rocking him gently in her arms.
origin: Middle English mollifien, from Middle French mollifier, from Late Latin mollificare, from Latin mollis soft; akin to Greek amaldynein to soften, Sanskrit mṛdu soft, and probably to Greek malakos soft, amblys dull, Old English meltan to melt

definition: giving admonition : warning
sentence: The teacher gave the class a monitory look to remind them that it was time to be quiet.
origin: Middle English, from Latin monitorius, from monēre

definition: a painting, drawing, or photograph in a single hue
sentence: The artist created a monochrome painting using only different shades of blue.
origin: Medieval Latin monochroma, from Latin, feminine of monochromos of one color, from Greek monochrōmos, from mon- + -chrōmos -chrome

definition: produced by, being, composed of, or caused by cells derived from a single cell; especially : relating to, being, or caused by a monoclonal antibody or monoclonal antibodies
sentence: Doctors use monoclonal antibodies to help target specific germs inside a person's body.

definition: a setting or mounting for a jewel; also a frame or support.
sentence: The jeweler carefully placed the diamond into the gold monture, which is the frame that holds the gem.

definition: a legally authorized period of delay in the performance of a legal obligation or the payment of a debt
sentence: The city announced a moratorium on building new houses until the old roads were fixed.
origin: New Latin, from Late Latin, neuter of moratorius dilatory, from Latin morari to delay, from mora delay

definition: biting and caustic in thought, manner, or style : incisive
sentence: The writer was known for his mordant humor, which was very sharp and a little bit biting.
origin: Middle French, present participle of mordre to bite, from Latin mordēre; perhaps akin to Sanskrit mṛdnāti he presses, rubs

definition: a branch of biology that deals with the form and structure of animals and plants
sentence: Scientists look at the morphological features of a plant, like its shape and size, to name it.

definition: undertaker
sentence: A mortician is a person whose job is to help families prepare for a funeral.

definition: a brand of ibuprofen used for treating pain and fever.
sentence: When I had a fever, my mom gave me some Motrin to help me feel better.

definition: a musical movement or the speed at which a piece is played.
sentence: In the music piece, the composer marked a nuovo movimento to show the song should speed up.

definition: a moist white unsalted unripened cheese of mild flavor and a smooth rubbery texture
sentence: I love the way the white mozzarella cheese stretches when I pull a slice of hot pizza.
origin: Italian, diminutive of mozza, a kind of cheese, from mozzare to cut off, from mozzo cut off, docked, from Vulgar Latin *mutius, alteration of Latin mutilus

definition: a young girl or female servant.
sentence: In my Spanish storybook, the muchacha helped her mother pick flowers in the garden.

definition: a free shot sometimes given a golfer in informal play when the previous shot was poorly played
sentence: Since it was just a practice game, the coach let the boy take a mulligan and try his hit again.

definition: having several broods in a season
sentence: Silkworms are often multivoltine, which means they can hatch and grow several times in one year.
origin: multi- + -voltine having a given number of broods (from French, from Italian volta time, turn)

definition: city on the Isar River in southern Germany population 1,348,335
sentence: Munich is a famous city in Germany known for its beautiful parks and old buildings.

definition: of or relating to the internal affairs of a major political unit (such as a nation)
sentence: The municipal swimming pool is run by the city and is open to everyone who lives there.
origin: Latin municipalis of a municipality, from municip-, municeps inhabitant of a municipality, from munus duty, service + capere to take ,

definition: bog; especially : a sphagnum bog of northern North America often with tussocks
sentence: In the north, we had to be careful walking through the muskeg, which is a very soggy, mossy swamp.

definition: a soldier armed with a musket
sentence: The three musketeers were brave soldiers who promised to always protect the king.
origin: modification of Middle French mousquetaire, from mousquet

definition: a loose often long dress having bright colors and patterns and adapted from the dresses originally distributed by missionaries to the native women of Hawaii
sentence: My aunt wore a colorful, flowy muumuu dress to the beach to stay cool in the sun.
origin: Hawaiian mu'umu'u, from mu'umu'u cut off

definition: —used for a polyester film
sentence: We bought a shiny Mylar balloon that stayed floating in the air for a whole week.

definition: inflammation of the myocardium
sentence: Myocarditis is a medical condition where the muscle of the heart becomes red and swollen.

definition: a red iron-containing protein pigment in muscles that is similar to hemoglobin
sentence: Myoglobin is a protein in your muscles that helps store oxygen so you can run and play.

definition: affected by myopia : of, relating to, or exhibiting myopia : nearsighted
sentence: If you are myopic, you can see things clearly when they are close, but far away things look blurry.

definition: a creating of myth : a giving rise to myths
sentence: The author had a mythopoeic imagination and created an entire world full of dragons and magic.
origin: borrowed from Greek mȳthopoiía, from mŷthos "utterance, tale, " + -o-  + -poiia (from poieîn "to make, produce, do" + -ia )

definition: a provincial governor of the Mogul empire in India
sentence: The nabobs in the story were very wealthy people who lived in giant houses filled with gold.
origin: Hindi navāb & Urdu nawāb, from Arabic nuwwāb, plural of nā'ib governor

definition: country on the Atlantic Ocean in southwestern Africa that is bisected by the Tropic of Capricorn; capital Windhoek area 318,261 square miles (824,292 square kilometers), population 2,533,000
sentence: We saw a picture of a Namibian desert with giant orange sand dunes that looked like mountains.

definition: a person who is subject to attacks of narcolepsy
sentence: The narcoleptic dog would suddenly fall fast asleep right in the middle of playing fetch.

definition: a crustacean larva in usually the first stage after leaving the egg and with three pairs of appendages, a median eye, and little or no segmentation
sentence: A nauplius is the very first stage of a baby crustacean, like a tiny swimming shrimp.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, a shellfish, from Greek nauplios

definition: any of a genus (Nautilus) of cephalopod mollusks of the South Pacific and Indian oceans with a spiral chambered shell that is pearly on the inside —called also chambered nautilus
sentence: The nautilus is a sea creature with a beautiful spiral shell that has many different chambers inside.
origin: New Latin, from Latin, paper nautilus, from Greek nautilos, literally, sailor, from naus ship

definition: a native or inhabitant of Naples, Italy
sentence: Neapolitan ice cream is a treat that has chocolate, vanilla, and strawberry all in one box.
origin: Middle English, from Latin neapolitanus of Naples, from Greek neapolitēs citizen of Naples, from Neapolis Naples

definition: a peach with a smooth-skinned fruit that is a frequent somatic mutation of the normal peach; also : its fruit
sentence: A nectarine looks like a peach but has smooth skin instead of fuzzy skin.

definition: a branch of medicine concerned with the care, development, and diseases of newborn infants
sentence: Neonatology is the part of medicine where doctors take special care of tiny newborn babies.

definition: the introduction or use of a new word or expression; an innovation.
sentence: The student came up with a neoterism, or a brand new word, to describe her favorite game.

definition: favoritism (as in appointment to a job) based on kinship
sentence: It was considered nepotism when the boss hired his own son instead of the person who was better at the job.
origin: French népotisme, from Italian nepotismo, from nepote nephew, from Latin nepot-, nepos grandson, nephew

definition: etiquette governing communication on the Internet
sentence: Using good netiquette means being kind and polite when you are talking to people on the internet.

definition: damage, disease, or dysfunction of one or more nerves especially of the peripheral nervous system that is typically marked by burning or shooting pain, numbness, tingling, or muscle weakness or atrophy, is often degenerative, and is usually caused by injury, infection, disease, drugs, toxins, or vitamin deficiency
sentence: Neuropathy is a problem with the nerves that can make a person's hands or feet feel tingly.
origin: + , probably after Italian neuropatia or French névropathie

definition: a neurotic character, condition, or trait
sentence: High neuroticism can make a person feel more worried or nervous about small things than others.

definition: any of a breed of very large heavy highly intelligent black, black-and-white, brown, or gray dogs having a thick coat and probably developed in Newfoundland
sentence: The Newfoundland is a giant dog with thick fur that is very good at swimming and rescuing people.

definition: a rechargeable storage battery that has a nickel cathode and a cadmium anode
sentence: We put a nicad battery in the toy car because it can be recharged and used over and over again.

definition: a salt or ester of nitric acid
sentence: Plants need nitrate, which is a type of nitrogen found in the soil, to help them grow big and green.

definition: harmful, injurious, or noxious.
sentence: The scientist warned that the chemicals were nocive and could be harmful to the little fish.

definition: a person who walks while asleep : sleepwalker
sentence: A noctambulist is a person who sleepwalks and moves around the house while they are still dreaming.
origin: New Latin noctambulus "sleepwalker" (earlier noctambulō, with -ōn-, -ō, agent suffix, from Latin noct-, nox  + -ambul-, noun derivative of ambulāre "to walk") +

definition: no-good, lowlife
sentence: The villain’s sidekick was a little bit of a no-goodnik who was always getting into trouble.

definition: divination based on the letters of a person's name.
sentence: In ancient stories, nomancy was a way of trying to tell the future by looking at a person's name.

definition: name, designation
sentence: In science, we use a special nomenclature to give every animal a name that scientists everywhere understand.
origin: borrowed from Latin nōmenclātūra "assigning of names to things," from nōmen "name" + calātus, past participle of calāre "to announce, proclaim" + -ūra  ,

definition: fear or anxiety caused by being without a mobile phone or being unable to use it.
sentence: Nomophobia is the feeling of being nervous when you don't have your cell phone with you.

definition: minority
sentence: Because he was still in his nonage, the boy had to wait until he was eighteen to vote.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from non- + age age

definition: the quality or state of being nonchalant
sentence: Even though he had just won the race, Leo showed a lot of nonchalance and acted like it was no big deal.

definition: not volatile: such as
sentence: The computer's nonvolatile memory keeps your saved games safe even when you turn the power off.

definition: any of a genus (Norovirus) of small, round, single-stranded RNA viruses that includes a single species (N. norwalkense) with various strains causing gastroenteritis in people and animals (such as cows, pigs, and dogs)
sentence: Our whole class stayed home because a Norovirus was making everyone feel sick to their stomachs.
origin: New Latin, from English Norwalk virus + New Latin -o- + virus

definition: 1503—1566 Michel de Notredame or Nostredame French physician and astrologer
sentence: Nostradamus was a famous man from history who wrote down many mysterious predictions about the future.

definition: the quality or state of being notorious
sentence: The sneaky thief gained notoriety for being able to escape from any jail cell.
origin: Middle French or Medieval Latin; Middle French notorieté, from Medieval Latin notorietat-, notorietas, from notorius

definition: a number equal to 1 followed by 60 zeros; also, British : a number equal to 1 followed by 114 zeros
sentence: A novemdecillion is a giant number that has sixty zeros after the number one!
origin: Latin novemdecim nineteen (from novem + decem ten) + English -illion (as in million)

definition: physically harmful or destructive to living beings
sentence: The noxious fumes from the old truck made everyone on the sidewalk cough.
origin: Middle English noxius, borrowed from Latin noxius "guilty, delinquent, harmful, injurious" (derivative of noxa "injurious behavior, harm, mischief") + -us ; noxa derivative (perhaps with -s- as a desiderative suffix) from the base of nocēre "to damage (things), injure, harm (persons)," going back to Indo-European *noḱ-éi̯e- "destroy" (with semantic weakening in Latin), whence also Sanskrit nāśáyati "(s/he) destroys," causative derivatives from a verbal base *neḱ- "disappear, pass out of existence, perish," whence, with varying ablaut grades, Sanskrit náśyati "(s/he) is lost, perishes," Avestan nąsat̰ "has gone away, is lost," Tocharian B näk- "destroy," (in middle voice) "disappear, be destroyed"

definition: region and ancient kingdom in northeastern Africa along the Nile in southern Egypt and northern Sudan
sentence: Nubia was an ancient kingdom in Africa that was famous for its powerful archers and gold.

definition: a soft sueded leather
sentence: My new shoes are made of soft nubuck leather that feels a bit like velvet.

definition: shaped like a nut.
sentence: The small pebble was nuciform, which means it was shaped exactly like a nut.

definition: having a nucleus or nuclei
sentence: In biology, a nucleated cell is a cell that has a nucleus, which is like the brain of the cell.

definition: the study of the occult significance of numbers
sentence: Some people study numerology because they think certain numbers have a special or lucky meaning.

definition: the act of nodding the head
sentence: Scientists noticed a tiny nutation, or a little wobble, in the way the Earth spins in space.
origin: Latin nutation-, nutatio, from nutare to nod, rock

definition: the durable usually light brown fur of a nutria
sentence: A nutria is a large rodent that looks like a beaver and lives near rivers and lakes.
origin: borrowed from American Spanish, from Spanish, "otter," altered (with n of uncertain origin) from Latin lutra

definition: a ceremonial offering or gift presented to a superior in India.
sentence: In old stories, a nuzzer was a special gift that a person gave to a leader as a sign of respect.

definition: an award presented annually by a professional organization for notable achievement in plays performed off-Broadway
sentence: The actor was very happy to win an Obie award for her performance in the play.

definition: a political subdivision of Imperial Russia or a republic of the Soviet Union or of Russia
sentence: An oblast is a large area or district in some countries, like a state in the United States.

definition: neither perpendicular nor parallel : inclined
sentence: The sunlight came through the window at an oblique angle, creating long shadows across the floor.
origin: Middle English oblique, oblike, borrowed from Anglo-French oblic, oblique, borrowed from Latin oblīquus "slanting, transverse," from ob- "against, facing" + -līquus, of uncertain meaning and origin

definition: a strongly condemnatory utterance : abusive language
sentence: The dishonest player had to face the obloquy of the fans after he was caught cheating.
origin: Middle English obloquie, obloqui, borrowed from Anglo-French & Late Latin; Anglo-French obloquie, borrowed from Late Latin obloquium, from obloquī "to speak against, blame" (going back to Latin, "to break in on, interrupt," from ob- "against" + loquī "to speak") + Latin -ium, deverbal suffix of function or state

definition: to cloud over; to obscure or darken.
sentence: The thick fog began to obnebulate the mountain, making it impossible to see the peak.

definition: a solemn prayer or earnest entreaty.
sentence: The character in the book made an obsecration, which is a very serious and earnest plea for help.

definition: no longer in use or no longer useful
sentence: Cassette tapes are mostly obsolete now because everyone listens to music on their phones.
origin: Latin obsoletus, from past participle of obsolescere to grow old, become disused, perhaps from ob- toward + solēre to be accustomed

definition: a physician specializing in obstetrics
sentence: An obstetrician is a special doctor who helps mothers take care of their babies before they are born.

definition: the quality or state of being obstinate : stubbornness
sentence: His obstinacy made it hard for him to change his mind, even when everyone else agreed.

definition: marked by unruly or aggressive noisiness : clamorous
sentence: The obstreperous puppies were barking and running around the room, making a huge mess.
origin: Latin obstreperus, from obstrepere to clamor against, from ob- against + strepere to make a noise

definition: the state of being hidden from view or lost to notice
sentence: During an occultation, one planet or moon passes in front of another and hides it from our view.
origin: Middle English occultacion, borrowed from Latin occultātiōn-, occultātiō "concealment, interruption of light from a celestial body," from occultāre "to prevent from being seen, conceal, keep secret" + -tiōn- -tiō, suffix of verbal action

definition: the lands of the central and southern Pacific Ocean including Micronesia, Melanesia, and Polynesia (including New Zealand)
sentence: Oceanian culture includes the many beautiful traditions of people living on islands in the Pacific Ocean.

definition: a person whose age is in the eighties
sentence: My great-grandfather is an octogenarian, which means he is between eighty and eighty-nine years old.
origin: Latin octogenarius containing eighty, from octogeni eighty each, from octoginta eighty, from octo eight + -ginta (akin to viginti twenty)

definition: having eight eyes, as some spiders.
sentence: A spider is octonocular because it has eight eyes to help it see everything around it.

definition: to multiply by eight; consisting of eight identical copies.
sentence: The office had to octuplicate the form, making eight identical copies of the same paper.

definition: a lyric poem usually marked by exaltation of feeling and style, varying length of line, and complexity of stanza forms
sentence: An odist is a poet who specializes in writing long, beautiful poems that celebrate a person or thing.
origin: Middle French or Late Latin; Middle French, from Late Latin, from Greek ōidē, literally, song, from aeidein, aidein to sing; akin to Greek audē voice

definition: an instrument for measuring the distance traveled (as by a vehicle)
sentence: The odometer on the car's dashboard shows exactly how many miles the car has driven.
origin: French odomètre, from Greek hodometron, from hodos way, road + metron measure

definition: a king of Ithaca and Greek leader in the Trojan War who after the war wanders 10 years before reaching home
sentence: In the ancient story, Odysseus was a brave hero who spent ten years trying to sail home.

definition: the founder of an ancient Greek colony.
sentence: In old history, an oecist was a person who was chosen to lead a group of people to start a new town.

definition: medicinal
sentence: The botanist looked for officinal plants that could be used by doctors to make medicine.
origin: borrowed from New Latin officīnālis "used as a medicine (of plants)," from officīna "apothecary's shop" (going back to Latin, "workshop," contraction of opificīna, from opific-, opifex "craftsman, artificer" —from opi-, base of opis, *ops "power, ability" and oper-, opus "work, effort" + -fic-, -fex, derivative of facere "to make, do, bring about"— + -īna, suffix of place) + Latin -ālis  ,

definition: a member of the largest subdivision of the Teton Sioux people.
sentence: The Oglala are a group of Native American people who are part of the Lakota nation.

definition: an African ungulate mammal (Okapia johnstoni) that is closely related to the giraffe but has a relatively short neck, a coat typically of solid reddish chestnut on the trunk, yellowish white on the cheeks, and purplish-black and cream rings on the upper parts of the legs
sentence: The okapi looks like a mix between a giraffe and a zebra, with stripes on its legs and a long neck.
origin: Mvuba (language spoken west of Lake Edward, Democratic Republic of the Congo)

definition: margarine
sentence: My grandmother sometimes uses oleo, which is another name for margarine, instead of butter.

definition: of or relating to the sense of smell
sentence: Your olfactory sense is your sense of smell, which helps you enjoy the scent of fresh cookies.
origin: Latin olfactorius, from olfacere to smell, from olēre to smell + facere to do ,

definition: any of several slender-bodied, nocturnal, tree-dwelling mammals (genus Bassaricyon of the family Procyonidae) of Central and South American forests that are grayish to yellowish brown, have a long, bushy, faintly ringed tail, large eyes, and pointed snout, and are closely related to the raccoon and coatis
sentence: The olingo is a small, furry animal with a long tail that lives in the trees of the rainforest.
origin: borrowed from Panamanian Spanish, probably the same word as Honduran Spanish olingo "howler monkey," of undetermined origin

definition: reading or having read everything; having encyclopedic knowledge.
sentence: Because she reads ten books a week, the librarian said the girl was becoming omnilegent.

definition: having infinite awareness, understanding, and insight
sentence: In some stories, the narrator is omniscient and knows everything that every character is thinking.
origin: New Latin omniscient-, omnisciens, back-formation from Medieval Latin omniscientia

definition: burden
sentence: The onus is on the students to make sure they put their names on their homework papers.

definition: a repeated rhythmic bass accompaniment especially in a band; also : music featuring such accompaniment
sentence: The brass band played a loud oompah song that made everyone want to march along.

definition: obscurity of sense : unintelligibility
sentence: The opacity of the thick curtains helped keep the bedroom completely dark even during the day.
origin: Middle French opacité shadiness, from Latin opacitat-, opacitas, from opacus shaded, dark

definition: a marine fish of the Pacific coast of North America with blue-green eyes.
sentence: The opaleye is a green fish found in tide pools that is named for its bright, opal-blue eyes.

definition: tedious, wearisome
sentence: Building the giant Lego castle was an operose task that took the whole weekend to finish.
origin: borrowed from Latin operōsus "diligent, painstaking, laborious," from opera "activity, effort, work" + -ōsus

definition: a physician who specializes in ophthalmology
sentence: I went to see an ophthalmologist to get my eyes checked and see if I needed new glasses.

definition: expressive of opprobrium : scurrilous
sentence: The bully was scolded for using opprobrious language that was very disrespectful to others.
origin: Middle English, borrowed from Late Latin opprobriōsus, from Latin opprobrium  + -ōsus

definition: to fight against
sentence: The lawyer tried to oppugn the witness's story by showing that it didn't match the facts.
origin: Middle English oppugnen, opugnen "to attack, repudiate," borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French oppugner "to attack, assault, attack the truth of," borrowed from Latin oppugnāre "to attack, assault, oppose in speech or action," from ob-  + pugnāre "to fight"

definition: a constellation on the equator east of Taurus represented on charts by the figure of a hunter with belt and sword
sentence: On clear winter nights, you can easily spot the three bright stars that make up the belt of Orion.

definition: intersecting or lying at right angles
sentence: The two roads are orthogonal to each other, meaning they meet at a perfect ninety-degree angle.
origin: Middle French, from Latin orthogonius, from Greek orthogōnios, from orth- + gōnia angle

definition: the early morning prayer service in the Eastern Orthodox Church.
sentence: In some churches, the orthros is a special prayer service that is held very early in the morning.

definition: the act of yawning; drowsiness or inattention.
sentence: A giant oscitation, or yawn, escaped the sleepy puppy as he curled up on his bed.

definition: the act of kissing; also : kiss
sentence: The two grandmothers shared an osculatory greeting, pressing their cheeks together for a kiss.

definition: a native or inhabitant of Oslo, Norway.
sentence: A person who lives in Oslo, the capital of Norway, is known as an Osloite.

definition: a blue-gray or blue-black hard brittle very heavy polyvalent metallic element with a high melting point that is used especially as a catalyst and in hard alloys
sentence: Osmium is a very heavy metal that is often used to make the tips of fountain pens strong.
origin: Greek osmḗ "smell, odor" + ; osmḗ going back to *od-s-mā, noun derivative from the base of ózein "to smell, give off an odor"

definition: a large fish-eating hawk (Pandion haliaetus) with long wings that is dark brown above and mostly pure white below
sentence: The osprey is a large hawk that is a great fisher, often diving into the water to catch its prey.
origin: Middle English ospray, from Anglo-French *osfraie, from Latin ossifraga, a bird of prey

definition: a small bone or bony structure (such as the malleus, incus, or stapes)
sentence: An ossicle is one of the three tiny bones in your middle ear that help you hear sounds.
origin: Latin ossiculum, diminutive of oss-, os

definition: a depository for the bones of the dead
sentence: An ossuary is a special room or container used for keeping the bones of people who lived long ago.
origin: Late Latin ossuarium, from Latin, neuter of ossuarius of bones, from Old Latin ossua, plural of oss-, os

definition: in a manner that conceals or may conceal what is true or real
sentence: The cat was ostensibly sleeping, but one eye was open to watch the bird outside.

definition: a physician practicing osteopathic medicine
sentence: An osteopath is a doctor who helps people feel better by moving and stretching their muscles and joints.

definition: a member of a Turkish dynasty founded by Osman I that ruled the Ottoman Empire
sentence: I rested my feet on the soft, cushioned ottoman while I sat in the big armchair.

definition: wood sorrel
sentence: The oxalis plant has leaves that look like clover and pretty flowers that close up at night.
origin: New Latin, genus name, from Latin, wood sorrel, from Greek, from oxys sharp

definition: food; especially : a suspension or solution of nutrients in a state suitable for absorption
sentence: The simple book was like mental pabulum, providing easy information that was very simple to digest.
origin: Latin, food, fodder; akin to Latin pascere to feed

definition: a tower in eastern Asia usually with roofs curving upward at the division of each of several stories and erected as a temple or memorial
sentence: While visiting East Asia, we saw a beautiful pagoda with many different roof levels.
origin: Portuguese pagode statue of a deity, Hindu or Buddhist temple

definition: of, relating to, originating in, or being an era of geologic history that extends from the beginning of the Cambrian to the close of the Permian and is marked by the culmination of nearly all classes of invertebrates except the insects and in the later epochs by the appearance of terrestrial plants, amphibians, and reptiles; also : relating to the corresponding system of rocks
sentence: The Paleozoic era was a time long ago when the first fish, insects, and reptiles appeared on Earth.

definition: a loose outer coat or jacket.
sentence: In the old story, the gentleman put on his heavy wool paletot coat before stepping out into the snow.

definition: resembling a hand with the fingers spread: such as
sentence: A maple leaf is palmate because its lobes spread out from the center like the fingers on a hand.

definition: of, relating to, or located on or near the eyelids
sentence: The doctor checked my palpebral area, which is the skin and muscle that makes up the eyelid.
origin: Late Latin palpebralis, from Latin palpebra eyelid; akin to Latin palpare

definition: marked by trembling or throbbing
sentence: I felt a palpitant thumping in my chest after I finished running the race.

definition: a lightweight hat of natural-colored straw hand-plaited of narrow strips from the young leaves of the jipijapa; also : a machine-made imitation of this
sentence: The Panama Canal is a famous waterway that allows ships to travel between two giant oceans.
origin: American Spanish panamá, from Panama, Central America

definition: of or relating to bread or bread-making.
sentence: The baker studied panary science to learn exactly how flour and yeast turn into bread.

definition: unsmoked bacon used especially in Italian cuisine
sentence: My mom added some salty pancetta to the pasta sauce to give it extra flavor.
origin: Italian, from diminutive of pancia belly, paunch, from Latin pantic-, pantex

definition: a broad explanation or theory that purports to account for all phenomena but is often criticized as being too vague.
sentence: Saying 'hard work' is a panchreston because people use it as an answer for almost any problem.

definition: a large lobulated gland of vertebrates that secretes digestive enzymes and the hormones insulin and glucagon
sentence: The pancreas is an organ in your body that helps you digest food and control your blood sugar.
origin: New Latin, from Greek pankreas sweetbread, from pan- + kreas flesh, meat

definition: an optical instrument combining the telescope and microscope
sentence: The building was designed as a panopticon, so a guard in the center could see all the rooms at once.

definition: pantomimist
sentence: During the game, I had to use pantomime to act out 'brushing my teeth' without saying a word.
origin: Latin pantomimus, from pant- + mimus mime

definition: a tall perennial sedge (Cyperus papyrus) of the Nile valley
sentence: Ancient Egyptians made a type of paper called papyrus from the tall reeds that grew by the river.

definition: being the best of a kind : preeminent
sentence: The baker is a pastry chef par excellence, meaning he is the very best at making cakes.

definition: a plane curve generated by a point moving so that its distance from a fixed point is equal to its distance from a fixed line : the intersection of a right circular cone with a plane parallel to an element of the cone
sentence: When you throw a ball into the air, its path follows a curve called a parabola.
origin: borrowed from New Latin, borrowed from Greek parabolḗ "juxtaposition, placement of a figure in contact with another, parabola"

definition: an arbitrary constant whose value characterizes a member of a system (such as a family of curves); also : a quantity (such as a mean or variance) that describes a statistical population
sentence: The teacher set the parameters for the project, telling us exactly how long it should be.
origin: New Latin, from para- + Greek metron measure

definition: partial or complete paralysis of the lower half of the body with involvement of both legs that is usually due to injury or disease of the spinal cord in the thoracic or lumbar region
sentence: The brave athlete didn't let being paraplegic stop him from competing in the wheelchair race.
origin: New Latin, from Greek paraplēgiē hemiplegia, from para- + -plēgia -plegia

definition: a lightweight umbrella used as a sunshade
sentence: The woman held a colorful parasol to keep the sun off her face while she walked in the park.
origin: borrowed from French, "screen or canopy shielding from the sun," going back to Middle French, borrowed from Italian parasole, from para "(it) shields, keeps out" (3rd singular present of parare "to prepare, adorn, avert, shield") + sole "sun," going back to Latin sōl ,

definition: a small, decorative triangular dagger worn by high-ranking military officers in ancient Rome.
sentence: In the museum, we saw a parazonium, which was a short sword worn by officers in ancient Rome.

definition: an arrangement of rope for hoisting or lowering a cylindrical object by making fast the middle of the rope aloft and looping both ends around the object which rests in the loops and rolls in them as the ends are hauled up or paid out; also : a single line made fast at one end and passed around an object that is used similarly
sentence: The workers used a parbuckle, a system of ropes, to roll the heavy log up the ramp.

definition: —used for a board game adapted from pachisi
sentence: My family loves to play Parcheesi, a classic board game where you try to get all your pieces home.

definition: a raw hide soaked in lye to remove the hair and dried
sentence: Native Americans used a parfleche, which is a bag made of tough rawhide, to carry their belongings.
origin: Canadian French parflèche, from French parer to ward off + flèche arrow

definition: one that is despised or rejected : outcast
sentence: The student felt like a pariah when no one would sit with him after he was mean to the group.

definition: to bet in a parlay
sentence: The girl tried to parlay her small allowance into a big savings account by doing extra chores.
origin: verbal derivative (perhaps with conformation to  or French parler "to speak") of paroli "series of bets set up so that the original stake and winnings are placed on successive wagers," borrowed from French, borrowed from Italian, plural of parolo (stress on first syllable), of uncertain origin

definition: a very hard dry sharply flavored cheese that is sold grated or in wedges
sentence: I like to sprinkle extra Parmesan cheese on top of my spaghetti and meatballs.
origin: short for Parmesan cheese; Parmesan "of the city of Parma," borrowed from Middle French parmisan, probably borrowed from a western Upper Italian variant of Tuscan parmigiano, from Parma "Parma" + -igiano, adjective suffix of appurtenance, from Vulgar Latin *-ēs- (going back to Latin -ensis, adjective suffix of place) + Latin -iānus

definition: of or relating to a church parish
sentence: Some of my friends go to a parochial school, which is a school run by a local church.
origin: Middle English parochiall, from Anglo-French parochial, from Late Latin parochialis, from parochia parish

definition: a literary or musical work in which the style of an author or work is closely imitated for comic effect or in ridicule
sentence: The funny song was parodic, making fun of a famous pop star's serious music.
origin: Latin parodia, from Greek parōidia, from para- + aidein to sing

definition: a young salmon actively feeding in fresh water
sentence: A parr is a young salmon that has dark stripes and lives in the river before going to the ocean.

definition: a unit of measure for interstellar space that is equal to 3.26 light-years and is the distance to an object having a parallax of one second as seen from points separated by one astronomical unit
sentence: In science fiction movies, pilots often use a parsec to measure the huge distances between stars.

definition: the quality of being careful with money or resources : thrift
sentence: Because of his parsimony, the man refused to spend money even on a new pair of shoes.
origin: Middle English parcimony, borrowed from Latin parsimōnia, from pars-, perfect stem of parcere "to act sparingly, be thrifty (with), refrain from" (of uncertain origin) + -i-  + -mōnia, suffix of abstract nouns (going back to the Indo-European noun-forming suffix *-mĕ̄n-/*mŏ̄n- + the abstract noun formative *-i-)

definition: the quality or state of being partial : bias
sentence: The judge showed partiality by choosing his own daughter as the winner of the contest.

definition: of or relating to minute separate particles
sentence: Smoke is made of tiny particulate matter that can make it hard for people to breathe.

definition: bringing forth or about to bring forth young
sentence: The parturient cat found a quiet, cozy spot in the closet to have her kittens.
origin: borrowed from Latin parturient-, parturiens, present participle of parturīre "to be in labor, be ready to give birth," from partus (past participle of parere "to give birth to, bring into being, produce") + -urīre, desiderative suffix; parere, going back to Indo-European *perh3-/*pr̥h3- "bring forth, give rise to, produce," whence also Old Irish ernaid "(s/he) bestows, grants," Greek époron "(s/he) provided, gave, granted," Sanskrit pṛṇā́ti "(s/he) gives, bestows"

definition: parvovirus
sentence: We had to take the puppy to the vet to get a vaccine so he wouldn't get sick with parvo.

definition: a fine wool similar to cashmere made from the undercoat of domestic Himalayan goats; also : a shawl made from this wool
sentence: My mom wore a soft pashmina shawl over her shoulders to stay warm during the evening party.
origin: Persian, from pashmin woolen, from pashm wool

definition: out of date; no longer fashionable.
sentence: My older brother thinks my favorite cartoon is passé and that I should watch cooler shows.

definition: to subject to pasteurization
sentence: Factories pasteurize milk by heating it up to kill any germs that might make people sick.

definition: a highly seasoned smoked beef prepared especially from shoulder cuts
sentence: For lunch, my dad made a sandwich with thin slices of spicy pastrami and mustard.
origin: Yiddish pastrame, from Romanian pastramă pressed and cured meat

definition: a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee and protects the front of the joint : kneecap
