definition: any of a genus (Sedum) of widely distributed fleshy herbs of the orpine family
sentence: Sedum is a type of plant with thick leaves that stores water and has pretty star-shaped flowers.

definition: to suffer violent internal excitement
sentence: You could see him start to seethe with anger when he realized someone had taken his toy.
origin: Middle English sethen, from Old English sēothan; akin to Old High German siodan to seethe and probably to Old Lithuanian siausti (it) storms, rages

definition: a variety of gypsum occurring in transparent crystals or crystalline masses
sentence: Selenite is a clear or white mineral that looks like a beautiful, shiny crystal.
origin: Middle English selinete, from Latin selenites, from Greek selēnitēs (lithos), literally, stone of the moon, from selēnē; from the belief that it waxed and waned with the moon

definition: a member of any of several groups of Indigenous people that emigrated to Florida from Georgia and Alabama in the 18th and 19th centuries and whose descendants now live in southern Florida and Oklahoma
sentence: The Seminole are a group of Native American people who originally lived in Florida.
origin: Creek simanó·li untamed, wild, alteration of simaló·ni, from American Spanish cimarrón wild

definition: any of a large genus (Senecio) of widely distributed composite plants that have alternate or basal leaves and flower heads usually with yellow ray flowers
sentence: The senecio plant in the garden has small yellow flowers that look like daisies.
origin: borrowed from New Latin Senecio, genus name, going back to Latin seneciōn-, seneciō "old man, groundsel," from senec-, variant stem of sen-, senex "old, aged, old man" + -iōn-, -iō, suffix forming appellatives from adjectives

definition: an agent or steward in charge of a lord's estate in feudal times
sentence: In a castle, the seneschal was a person whose job was to manage all the servants and the food.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, of Germanic origin; akin to Goth sineigs old and to Old High German scalc servant

definition: any of a genus (Senna synonym Cassia) of leguminous herbs, shrubs, and trees native to warm regions; especially : one used medicinally
sentence: Senna is a plant whose leaves are sometimes used to make a type of medicine.

definition: a teacher or instructor usually of Japanese martial arts (such as karate or judo)
sentence: In karate class, we always bow to our sensei to show respect for our teacher.

definition: occurring or being done every seven years
sentence: A septennial event is something that only happens once every seven years.
origin: Late Latin septennium period of seven years, from Latin septem + -ennium (as in biennium)

definition: a dividing wall or membrane especially between bodily spaces or masses of soft tissue
sentence: The septum is the thin wall inside your nose that separates your two nostrils.
origin: New Latin, from Latin saeptum enclosure, fence, wall, from saepire to fence in, from saepes fence, hedge

definition: of or relating to a sepulchre
sentence: The basement was quiet and sepulchral, making it feel a little bit spooky.

definition: of or relating to seraphim
sentence: The choir sang with seraphic voices that sounded like beautiful music from heaven.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin seraphicus, from Late Latin seraphim  + -icus

definition: obtained or characterized by serendipity
sentence: It was serendipitous that I found my lost ring while I was looking for a completely different toy.

definition: to mark or make with serrations
sentence: The bread knife has a serrated edge, which means it has small teeth to help it cut through crust.
origin: Late Latin serratus, past participle of serrare to saw, from Latin serra

definition: a widely cultivated chiefly tropical or subtropical annual erect herb (Sesamum indicum of the family Pedaliaceae); also : its small seeds used especially as a source of oil and a flavoring agent
sentence: My favorite bagel is covered in tiny, crunchy sesame seeds.
origin: alteration of earlier sesam, sesama, from Latin sesamum, sesama, from Greek sēsamon, sēsamē, of Semitic origin; akin to Akkadian šamaššamu sesame

definition: a long seat with a back
sentence: Grandma invited us to sit on the small velvet settee in her living room to listen to a story.

definition: the act or process of severing : the state of being severed
sentence: When the branch was broken off the tree, it was a complete severance from the main trunk.

definition: a perennial onion (Allium cepa var. aggregatum) that produces small clustered bulbs which resemble those of garlic and are used in cooking; also : its bulb
sentence: A shallot is like a small onion that has a milder and sweeter taste when you cook it.
origin: modification of French échalote, from Middle French eschalotte, alteration of eschaloigne, from Vulgar Latin *escalonia

definition: a priest or priestess who uses magic for the purpose of curing the sick, divining the hidden, and controlling events
sentence: In some cultures, a shaman is a person who is believed to have a special connection to the spirit world.
origin: ultimately from Evenki (Tungusic language of Siberia) šamān

definition: Yitzhak 1915—2012 originally surname Yizernitzky prime minister of Israel (1983—84; 1986—92)
sentence: In old legends, a shamir was a magical worm that could cut through the hardest stone.

definition: a traditional Irish storyteller.
sentence: A shanachie is a traditional Irish storyteller who knows many old legends and folktales.

definition: a sandwich especially of sliced lamb or chicken, vegetables, and often tahini wrapped in pita bread
sentence: For lunch, we had shawarma, which is tasty meat wrapped in a soft piece of pita bread.
origin: Levantine Arabic shāwurma sliced lamb on a skewer, from Turkish çevirme, literally, turn, rotation, from çevir- turn

definition: used to introduce a sudden or magical transformation or occurrence.
sentence: The magician shouted 'shazam!' and a rabbit suddenly appeared from inside his hat.

definition: everything involved in what is under consideration —usually used in the phrase the whole shebang
sentence: We decided to clean the whole room, from the toys to the books—the whole shebang!

definition: shelduck
sentence: A sheldrake is a large, colorful duck that often lives near the coast.
origin: Middle English, from sheld- (akin to Middle Dutch schillede parti-colored) + drake

definition: river 55 miles (88 kilometers) long in northern Virginia flowing northeast between the Allegheny and Blue Ridge Mountains across the northeastern tip of West Virginia and into the Potomac River and forming the Shenandoah Valley
sentence: We visited the Shenandoah Valley, which is a beautiful place with mountains and a long river.

definition: activity or behavior that is not honest or proper : deceptive or questionable practices or conduct —usually used in plural
sentence: The kittens were up to their usual shenanigans, chasing each other and hiding in boxes.

definition: shetland pony
sentence: A Shetland pony is a small and very strong horse that originally came from islands near Scotland.

definition: to go stealthily : sneak
sentence: You shouldn't shirk your duties, like cleaning your room, even if you'd rather be playing.

definition: a paper screen serving as a wall, partition, or sliding door
sentence: In a Japanese house, a shoji is a sliding door made of a wooden frame and paper.

definition: a device with meshes or perforations through which finer particles of a mixture (as of ashes, flour, or sand) of various sizes may be passed to separate them from coarser ones, through which the liquid may be drained from liquid-containing material, or through which soft materials may be forced for reduction to fine particles
sentence: My mom used a sieve to strain the water out of the pasta after it was cooked.
origin: Middle English sive, from Old English sife; akin to Old High German sib sieve

definition: a traditional Korean poetic form, typically consisting of three lines.
sentence: In school, we learned about sijo, which is a traditional type of poem that comes from Korea.

definition: agreeable, likable
sentence: The two new friends were very simpatico and liked all the same games and books.
origin: Italian simpatico & Spanish simpático, ultimately from Latin sympathia sympathy

definition: existing or occurring at the same time : exactly coincident
sentence: The simultaneity of the two bells ringing at the exact same time was quite surprising.
origin: borrowed from Medieval Latin simultāneus "occurring at the same time," from Latin simul "in company, together, at the same time" (going back to an apocopated neuter form of similis "having characteristics in common, like") + Medieval Latin -tāneus, as in instantāneus , Late Latin momentāneus "momentary," spontāneus "voluntary, unconstrained, "

definition: the medical term for a hiccup.
sentence: Singultus is the medical word for a hiccup, which happens when your tummy muscle jerks.

definition: any of an order (Sirenia) of aquatic herbivorous mammals (such as a manatee, dugong, or Steller's sea cow) that have large forelimbs resembling paddles, no hind limbs, and a flattened tail resembling a fin
sentence: A manatee is a type of sirenian, which is a large and gentle animal that lives in the water.
origin: New Latin Sirenia, from Latin siren

definition: a star of the constellation Canis Major that is the brightest star in the heavens —called also Dog Star
sentence: Sirius is the brightest star in the night sky and is often called the 'Dog Star.'
origin: Middle English, from Latin, from Greek Seirios

definition: a hot dust-laden wind from the Libyan deserts that blows on the northern Mediterranean coast chiefly in Italy, Malta, and Sicily
sentence: A sirocco is a hot and dusty wind that blows from Africa across the ocean toward Europe.
origin: Italian scirocco, sirocco, alteration of Old Italian scilocco, from Arabic dialect (Maghreb) šlōq southeast wind, alteration of Arabic shalūq, shulūq

definition: a strong white fiber used especially for cordage and twine —called also sisal hemp
sentence: The rug was made of sisal, which is a strong fiber that comes from the leaves of a plant.

definition: a small chiefly greenish and yellowish finch (Spinus spinus) of Europe, Asia, and northern Africa that is related to the goldfinch
sentence: A siskin is a small, green and yellow bird that belongs to the finch family.
origin: German dialect Sisschen, diminutive of Middle High German zīse siskin, of Slav origin; akin to Czech čížek siskin

definition: a genus of weevils that are destructive to leguminous plants.
sentence: A Sitona is a type of small beetle that likes to eat the leaves of clover and beans.

definition: of or relating to the nuthatches (birds).
sentence: The nuthatch has a sittine way of moving, often hopping down a tree trunk with its head facing the ground.

definition: skiing in a zigzag or wavy course between upright obstacles (such as flags)
sentence: In the winter, we watched the skiers race down the mountain in a slalom through many gates.

definition: a meat stew
sentence: Grandpa made a big pot of slumgullion stew using all the leftover vegetables from the week.
origin: perhaps from slum slime + English dialect gullion mud, cesspool

definition: a habitual faultfinder or a discontented traveler.
sentence: Don't be a smellfungus who only talks about things they don't like instead of things they do.

definition: small broken pieces : fragments, bits —usually used in phrases like blow to smithereens, smash to smithereens, or blast to smithereens
sentence: When the glass hit the floor, it broke into tiny smithereens that were very hard to clean up.

definition: quick, acute
sentence: A snell is a short piece of line used to attach a fishhook to the main fishing line.
origin: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German snel bold, agile

definition: a sobersided person
sentence: The character in the book was a real sobersides who never laughed at any of the funny jokes.

definition: a wise and skillful lawgiver
sentence: A solon is a wise leader who helps to make good rules and laws for the city.

definition: body type : physique
sentence: A person's somatotype describes the general shape of their body, like if they are tall and thin.

definition: the act or habit of talking in one's sleep.
sentence: My brother's somniloquy is funny because he sometimes talks about pizza while he is fast asleep.

definition: a person who predicts the future by magical, intuitive, or more rational means : prognosticator
sentence: In old stories, a soothsayer was a person who claimed they could tell what would happen in the future.

definition: conceited and overconfident of knowledge but poorly informed and immature
sentence: The boy was told to stop acting in a sophomoric way and to be more mature and helpful.

definition: sentimental, mawkish
sentence: The movie was filled with soppiness and everyone was crying by the end of it.

definition: one who practices divination by drawing lots.
sentence: In the fantasy book, a sortileger used magic to try and find the hidden treasure.

definition: an old name for a sulfate of iron or a similar mineral.
sentence: I felt sory for the little bird that had fallen out of its nest and tried to help it.

definition: relating to salvation or a savior (a variant or combined form of soterial).
sentence: The monk spoke of a sorysoterial hope, which meant he believed in a way to save people from their troubles.

definition: of or relating to salvation.
sentence: In the story, the magic potion had soterial powers because it could heal any sickness in the land.

definition: of or relating to Sirius, the Dog Star.
sentence: The ancient Egyptians used a Sothic calendar, which was based on the movement of the very bright star Sirius.

definition: a large circular tuba that has a flared adjustable bell
sentence: During the parade, the musician wore a giant sousaphone that wrapped around his body and made deep, booming sounds.

definition: a member of any of several breeds of small or medium-sized mostly short-legged dogs usually having long wavy hair, feathered legs and tail, and large drooping ears
sentence: Our neighbor has a friendly Cocker Spaniel with long, floppy ears and a very waggy tail.
origin: Middle English spaynel, spaniell, from Anglo-French espainnel, alteration of espaignol Spaniard, from Vulgar Latin *Hispaniolus, from Latin Hispania Spain

definition: a type of long sword used by the Roman army.
sentence: The museum had a spatha, which was a long, straight sword used by Roman soldiers many years ago.

definition: a sheathing bract or pair of bracts partly enclosing an inflorescence and especially a spadix on the same axis
sentence: A spathe is a large, leaf-like part that grows around the flowers of plants like calla lilies.
origin: New Latin spatha, from Latin, broadsword

definition: the process of biological species formation
sentence: Our science teacher explained speciation, which is how one group of animals slowly turns into a new species over a long time.

definition: an instrument used for measuring wavelengths of light spectra
sentence: The scientist used a spectrometer to look at the light from the sun and figure out what gases are in it.

definition: spiny
sentence: The spinosity of the cactus makes it very prickly and protects it from being eaten by desert animals.

definition: a breathing hole : vent
sentence: An insect doesn't have a nose like ours; instead, it breathes through tiny holes on its body called a spiracle.
origin: Middle English, from Latin spiraculum, from spirare to breathe

definition: a microscopic filamentous aquatic cyanobacterium (genus Spirulina, especially S. platensis synonym Arthrospira platensis) that is sometimes cultivated for use as food especially as a dietary supplement
sentence: My mom puts a scoop of green spirulina powder in her smoothie because it is full of healthy vitamins.
origin: New Latin, from spirula small coil, diminutive of Latin spira coil

definition: given to melancholy
sentence: The grumpy man was in a splenetic mood and complained about everything from the weather to his lunch.
origin: Late Latin spleneticus, from Latin splen spleen

definition: a formal betrothal or engagement to be married.
sentence: In history class, we learned that sponsalia was a special ceremony for couples who were planning to get married.

definition: the quality or state of being spontaneous
sentence: We decided to have a picnic with a lot of spontaneity, just grabbing a blanket and heading to the park without planning it.
origin: borrowed from New Latin spontāneitāt-, spontāneitās, from Late Latin spontāneus "voluntary, unconstrained, " + Latin -itāt-, -itās

definition: full of life and vivacity : spirited
sentence: Even though she is quite old, my grandmother has a wonderful sprightliness and can still outrun me in the garden.

definition: the waste piece on a casting (as of metal or plastic) left by the hole through which the mold was filled
sentence: The doctor checked to see if the patient had sprue, a sickness that makes it hard for the body to get nutrients from food.

definition: outwardly similar or corresponding to something without having its genuine qualities : false
sentence: The claim that the moon is made of green cheese is completely spurious and not based on facts.
origin: Late Latin & Latin; Late Latin spurius false, from Latin, of illegitimate birth, from spurius, noun, bastard

definition: persistent inflation combined with stagnant consumer demand and relatively high unemployment
sentence: Stagflation is a difficult time for a country when prices go up but people don't have enough jobs.

definition: marked by settled sedateness and often prim self-restraint : sober, grave
sentence: The library was a very staid place where everyone sat quietly and worked without making any noise.

definition: marked by outstanding strength and vigor of body, mind, or spirit
sentence: The stalwart knight refused to leave his post and protected the castle gates all through the night.
origin: Middle English, alteration of stalworth, from Old English stǣlwierthe serviceable

definition: one versed in or engaged in compiling statistics
sentence: A statistician is a person who is an expert at collecting and studying large groups of numbers.

definition: resembling a statue especially in dignity, shapeliness, or stillness; especially : having a tall and shapely form
sentence: The tall, statuesque woman stood very still and looked like she could be a work of art in the museum.

definition: having, showing, or conferring prestige
sentence: Having the newest, fanciest smartphone is considered very statusy by some of the older kids.

definition: to stow especially in a ship's hold
sentence: The sailors had to steeve the cargo, which means they packed it tightly into the bottom of the ship.
origin: probably from Spanish estibar or Portuguese estivar to pack tightly, from Latin stipare to press together

definition: any of a suborder (Stegosauria) of quadrupedal ornithischian herbivorous dinosaurs chiefly of the Jurassic with strongly developed dorsal plates and spikes
sentence: The stegosaur was a dinosaur with large, bony plates on its back and a tail with sharp spikes.

definition: a neckcloth with long ends loosely tied or tucked through a buttonhole, fashionable in the 17th century.
sentence: In the old painting, the man wore a steinkirk, which is a type of necktie that is loosely tied.

definition: shaped like a small star.
sentence: The scientist studied the stellar system and described it as having a complex, stellular structure.

definition: extremely loud
sentence: The principal used a stentorian voice that could be heard all the way across the noisy cafeteria.

definition: one of the vast usually level and treeless tracts in southeastern Europe or Asia
sentence: A steppe is a giant, flat grassland with very few trees that stretches for miles and miles.

definition: any of a genus (Stevia) of composite herbs and shrubs of tropical and subtropical America; especially : a white-flowered tender perennial (S. rebaudiana) native to Paraguay
sentence: My dad uses stevia to sweeten his tea because it comes from a plant and has no sugar.
origin: New Latin, from Petrus Jacobus Stevus (Pedro Jaime Esteve) †1555 Spanish physician and botanist

definition: something that rouses or incites to activity: such as
sentence: Bright lights and loud noises are stimuli that can make a baby start to cry.

definition: to make an agreement or covenant to do or forbear something : contract
sentence: The rules of the game stipulate that you must wait your turn and not peek at other people's cards.
origin: Latin stipulatus, past participle of stipulari to demand a guarantee (from a prospective debtor)

definition: the act or process of stratifying
sentence: In the Grand Canyon, you can see the stratification of the earth in the different colored layers of rock.

definition: a form of government in which the military has control.
sentence: A stratocracy is a type of government where the leaders of the army are the ones in charge of the country.

definition: the part of the earth's atmosphere which extends from the top of the troposphere to about 30 miles (50 kilometers) above the surface and in which temperature increases gradually to about 32°F (0°C) and clouds rarely form
sentence: The stratosphere is a layer of the Earth's atmosphere that is high above where most airplanes fly.
origin: borrowed from French stratosphère, probably from stratus  (from the zone's layer-like character, compared to stratus clouds) + -o-  + -sphère

definition: the fact or state of being striated
sentence: We noticed a long striation, or scratch, on the rock that was made by a moving glacier a long time ago.

definition: an abnormal narrowing of a bodily passage; also : the narrowed part
sentence: The teacher put a stricture on talking in the hallway to make sure we didn't bother the other classes.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin strictura, from Latin strictus, past participle

definition: the quality or state of being strident
sentence: The stridency of the alarm clock's beep was so loud that it woke up everyone in the house.

definition: —used for an expanded rigid polystyrene plastic
sentence: We used Styrofoam cups for the party because they are lightweight and keep the drinks cool.

definition: to bring under control and governance as a subject : conquer
sentence: The mean king tried to subjugate his neighbors and make them follow his unfair rules.
origin: Middle English, from Latin subjugatus, past participle of subjugare, from sub- + jugum yoke

definition: inadequate to produce a sensation or a perception
sentence: A subliminal message is something that your brain notices without you even realizing you saw or heard it.

definition: partially dislocated, as a joint.
sentence: The athlete subluxated his shoulder, which means the bone moved slightly out of its proper place.

definition: capable of being submerged
sentence: The scientists used a small submersible to dive deep into the ocean and look at strange fish.

definition: wearing a slight or quiet smile.
sentence: The girl had a subrident expression, with just a tiny smile that showed she was happy.

definition: following in time, order, or place
sentence: We had a snack first, and then in the subsequent hour, we went outside to play tag.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin subsequent-, subsequens, present participle of subsequi to follow close, from sub- near + sequi to follow ,

definition: real being : existence
sentence: Subsistence farming is when a family grows just enough food to feed themselves.
origin: Middle English, from Late Latin subsistentia, from subsistent-, subsistens, present participle of subsistere

definition: substratum
sentence: The substrate at the bottom of our fish tank is made of small, colorful pebbles.

definition: deception by artifice or stratagem in order to conceal, escape, or evade
sentence: The spy used subterfuge, like wearing a wig and glasses, to hide his true identity.
origin: Late Latin subterfugium, from Latin subterfugere to escape, evade, from subter- secretly (from subter underneath; akin to Latin sub under) + fugere to flee ,

definition: being, lying, or operating under the surface of the earth
sentence: Some animals, like moles and earthworms, spend their whole lives in subterranean tunnels underground.
origin: Latin subterraneus, from sub- + terra earth

definition: the quality or state of being subtle
sentence: The artist used great subtlety in her painting, using very soft colors that slowly faded into each other.
origin: Middle English sotilte, subtilte, from Anglo-French sotilté, from Latin subtilitat-, subtilitas, from subtilis

definition: the act of subverting : the state of being subverted; especially : a systematic attempt to overthrow or undermine a government or political system by persons working secretly from within
sentence: The character in the story had a subversive plan to secretly change the rules of the school.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin subversion-, subversio, from Latin subvertere

definition: following in order : following each other without interruption
sentence: It has rained for three successive days, so we have had to stay inside since Monday.

definition: to yield to superior strength or force or overpowering appeal or desire
sentence: Even though he tried to stay awake, Leo finally had to succumb to sleep after the long day.
origin: French & Latin; French succomber, from Latin succumbere, from sub- + -cumbere to lie down; akin to Latin cubare to lie

definition: the hard fat about the kidneys and loins in beef and mutton that yields tallow
sentence: We hung a cake of suet in the tree to give the birds extra energy during the cold winter.
origin: Middle English sewet, from Anglo-French suet, siuet, from seu, su hard animal fat, from Latin sebum

definition: a short intercessory prayer usually in a series
sentence: Suffrage is the right to vote in an election and choose who will lead the country.
origin: Middle English, "help, aid, intercessory prayer, indulgence," borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Medieval Latin suffrāgium "vote, selection, aid, support, intercessory prayer," going back to Latin, "vote cast in an assembly, right to vote, decision reached by a vote, influence exerted in support of a candidate or policy," from suffrāgor, suffrāgārī "to express public support (for a candidate, measure, etc.), be favorable (toward)" (from suf-, assimilated form of sub-  + -frāg-, probably from the base of frangere, past participle frāctus, "to break, shatter") + -ium, deverbal suffix of function or state

definition: island of western Indonesia south of the Malay Peninsula area 182,542 square miles (472,784 square kilometers)
sentence: The Sumatran tiger is a very rare and beautiful animal that lives in the jungles of Indonesia.

definition: to issue a call to convene : convoke
sentence: The principal summoned the students to the office to give them their awards for the art contest.
origin: Middle English somnen, somonen, from Anglo-French somondre, from Vulgar Latin *summonere, alteration of Latin summonēre to remind secretly, from sub- secretly + monēre to warn ,

definition: extremely costly, rich, luxurious, or magnificent; also : magnificent
sentence: The royal banquet featured a sumptuous feast with every kind of food you can imagine.
origin: Middle English, from Latin sumptuosus, from sumptus

definition: the quality or state of being superficial
sentence: The teacher told us to look past the superficiality of the book's cover and read the story inside.

definition: of, relating to, or swayed by superstition
sentence: Some people are superstitious and think that seeing a black cat will bring them bad luck.
origin: Middle English supersticious, from Anglo-French supersticius, from Latin superstitiosus, from superstitio

definition: lying on the back or with the face upward
sentence: I lay in a supine position on the grass, looking straight up at the white clouds in the sky.
origin: Middle English suppyne, from Latin supinus; akin to Latin sub under, up to

definition: serving to supplement
sentence: My mom gave me a supplemental vitamin to make sure I grow up strong and healthy.

definition: to make a humble entreaty; especially : to pray to God
sentence: The people began to supplicate the king, asking him for help after the big storm.
origin: Middle English supplicaten "to make a request," borrowed from Latin supplicātus, past participle of supplicāre "to seek the goodwill (of a person wronged) with peace offerings, sue for forgiveness, beg humbly," derivative of supplic-, supplex "making humble entreaty, suppliant"

definition: the quality or state of being supreme; especially : a position of unquestioned authority, dominance, or influence
sentence: The two teams played a final game to decide which one would have supremacy in the league.

definition: to desist from action; also : to come to an end : cease
sentence: After the loud party ended, the quiet of the night provided a welcome surcease from the noise.
origin: Middle English sursesen, surcesen, from Anglo-French surceser, alteration of surseer, surseoir, from Latin supersedēre

definition: the state of being sure: such as
sentence: The boy spoke with great surety, knowing exactly what the answer to the question was.
origin: Middle English seurte, from Anglo-French seurté, from Latin securitat-, securitas security, from securus

definition: to prevail over : overcome
sentence: Even though the puzzle was difficult, we knew it was surmountable if we worked together.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French surmunter, from sur- + munter to mount

definition: the principles, ideals, or practice of producing fantastic or incongruous imagery or effects in art, literature, film, or theater by means of unnatural or irrational juxtapositions and combinations
sentence: We saw a surrealist painting that showed a melting clock hanging from a tree branch.
origin: French surréalisme, from sur- + réalisme realism

definition: close watch kept over someone or something (as by a detective); also : supervision
sentence: The bank has a surveillance camera to watch the lobby and make sure everyone stays safe.
origin: French, from surveiller to watch over, from sur- + veiller to watch, from Old French veillier, from Latin vigilare, from vigil watchful

definition: a low-lying or depressed and often wet stretch of land; also : a shallow depression on a golf course
sentence: A swale is a low, grassy area in the yard that helps the rain water drain away from the house.

definition: a servile self-seeking flatterer : one who praises those in power in order to gain their approval
sentence: The king was surrounded by sycophants who always told him he was right just to get his favor.
origin: borrowed from Latin sȳcophanta, borrowed from Greek sȳkophántēs, literally, "one who shows the fig," from sŷkon "fig" (perhaps in reference to an apotropaic gesture made by inserting the thumb between the index and second fingers) + -phantēs, agentive derivative of phaínein "to reveal, show, make known"; perhaps from the use of such a gesture in denouncing a culprit ,

definition: a summary outline of a discourse, treatise, or course of study or of examination requirements
sentence: On the first day of class, the teacher gave us a syllabus that listed everything we would learn.
origin: Late Latin, alteration of Latin sillybus label for a book, from Greek sillybos

definition: an elemental being in the theory of Paracelsus that inhabits air
sentence: In old stories, a sylph is a magical spirit of the air that is very thin and graceful.

definition: having, involving, or exhibiting symmetry
sentence: A butterfly is symmetrical because its left wing looks exactly like its right wing.

definition: a convivial party (as after a banquet in ancient Greece) with music and conversation
sentence: The scientists gathered for a symposium to talk about their new discoveries in space.
origin: Latin, from Greek symposion, from sympinein to drink together, from syn- + pinein to drink

definition: syndactyly
sentence: Syndactylism is a condition where a person or animal is born with two or more fingers or toes joined together.

definition: a council or body of syndics
sentence: A syndicate is a group of people or businesses that work together to finish a big project.

definition: to tune a radio or transmitter to a particular frequency.
sentence: The radio operator had to syntonize the equipment to make sure the signal was clear.

definition: a biological relationship where two different species rely on each other for nutrients.
sentence: In biology, syntrophism is when two different types of germs help each other to survive.

definition: a device used to inject fluids into or withdraw them from something (such as the body or its cavities): such as
sentence: The nurse used a small syringe to give the girl her medicine so she wouldn't get sick.
origin: Middle English syring, from Anglo-French siringe, from Medieval Latin syringa, from Late Latin, injection, from Greek syring-, syrinx panpipe, tube

definition: a house of worship; specifically : a large building or tent used for evangelistic services
sentence: A tabernacle is a special and holy building or container used in some religious ceremonies.
origin: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin tabernaculum, from Latin, tent, from taberna hut

definition: a building material consisting of a mixture of lime, sand, and shells.
sentence: In some parts of the world, a tabia is a type of fort or wall made from hard, packed earth.

definition: a graphic description or representation : picture
sentence: The students stood perfectly still to create a tableau of a famous scene from history.
origin: French, from Middle French tablel, diminutive of table, from Old French

definition: a room in an ancient Roman house, usually opening off the atrium, used for keeping records.
sentence: In an ancient Roman house, the tablinum was a room used as an office or a place to meet guests.

definition: to count, record, or list systematically
sentence: We had to tabulate the results of our class vote and put them into a neat chart.

definition: temperamentally disinclined to talk
sentence: The cowboy was a taciturn man who didn't say much and mostly kept to himself.
origin: French or Latin; French taciturne, from Middle French, from Latin taciturnus, from tacitus see

definition: a Korean art of unarmed self-defense characterized especially by the extensive use of kicks
sentence: In my tae kwon do class, I learned how to do a high kick and how to block a punch.
origin: Korean t'aekwŏndo, from t'ae- to kick + kwŏn fist + to way

definition: the hard nut of a South American palm, often called vegetable ivory.
sentence: Tagua is a very hard seed from a palm tree that can be carved to look just like ivory.

definition: an ancient Chinese discipline of meditative movements practiced as a system of exercises
sentence: My grandfather does tai chi in the park every morning to help him stay balanced and calm.
origin: Chinese (Beijing) tàijíquán, from tàijí the Absolute in Chinese cosmology + quán fist, boxing

definition: a moist subarctic forest dominated by conifers (such as spruce and fir) that begins where the tundra ends
sentence: The taiga is a giant forest in the north that is filled with pine trees and is very cold in the winter.

definition: a large heavily built bovid (Budorcas taxicolor) of Tibet and adjacent areas of Asia that is related to the goats and the musk ox and that has horns in both sexes arising near the midline of the head and sweeping abruptly outward and then backward and upward
sentence: A takin is a large, furry animal from the mountains of Asia that looks a bit like a goat-cow.

definition: an object held to act as a charm to avert evil and bring good fortune
sentence: Leo carried a smooth lucky stone as a talisman to help him feel brave during his speech.
origin: French talisman or Spanish talismán or Italian talismano; all from Arabic ṭilsam, from Middle Greek telesma, from Greek, consecration, from telein to initiate into the mysteries, complete, from telos end

definition: a French pastry or cheesecake made in the shape of a triangle.
sentence: A talmouse is a type of French pastry that is shaped like a triangle and filled with cheese.

definition: a small drum; especially : a shallow one-headed drum with loose metallic disks at the sides played especially by shaking or striking with the hand
sentence: I shook the tambourine and hit it against my hand to keep the beat during the song.
origin: Middle French tambourin, diminutive of tambour

definition: any of a breed of large long-bodied red swine developed in England especially for the production of bacon
sentence: The farmer had a Tamworth pig, which is a breed known for its reddish-brown hair.

definition: any of various mandarin oranges that have usually deep orange skin and pulp; broadly : mandarin
sentence: I peeled the sweet tangerine and shared the small orange slices with my friend.
origin: Tangerine (orange), from French Tanger Tangier, Morocco + English

definition: a fit of bad temper
sentence: The toddler had a big tantrum on the floor because he didn't want to leave the playground.

definition: a usually granular preparation of cassava starch used especially in puddings and as a thickening in liquid food; also : a dish (such as pudding) containing tapioca
sentence: My favorite dessert is warm tapioca pudding with its little boba-like pearls.

definition: a lever or projection moved by some other piece (such as a cam) or intended to tap or touch something else to cause a particular motion
sentence: A tappet is a small part inside an engine that moves up and down to help the valves work.

definition: a sheer cotton fabric in open plain weave usually heavily sized for stiffness
sentence: In the costume room, we saw a dress made of tarlatan, which is a thin, stiff cotton fabric.

definition: island in the South Pacific separated from the southeastern part of mainland Australia by Bass Strait
sentence: The Tasmanian devil is a small, noisy animal that is only found on a large island near Australia.

definition: a café in Greece
sentence: While visiting Greece, we ate dinner at a small taverna right by the edge of the blue sea.
origin: Modern Greek taberna, probably from Late Greek, drinking establishment, from Latin, hut, shop

definition: the art of preparing, stuffing, and mounting the skins of animals and especially vertebrates
sentence: The museum used taxidermy to show us exactly what the mountain lion looked like in real life.
origin: borrowed from French taxidermie, from Greek táxis "order, arrangement" + dérma "skin" + French -ie  ,

definition: the study of the general principles of scientific classification : systematics
sentence: Scientists use a taxonomic system to put every living thing into a specific group with a name.
origin: borrowed from French taxonomie, from Greek táxis "arrangement, order" + French -o-  + -nomie

definition: of or relating to tectonics

origin: probably borrowed from German tektonisch "pertaining to broader structural features of the earth's crust," earlier "of building or construction," borrowed from Late Latin tectonicus "of a builder or architect," borrowed from Greek tektonikós "of a carpenter, skilled in carpentry or building," from tekton-, téktōn "woodworker, carpenter, craftsman" + -ikos ; téktōn going back to Indo-European *tetḱ-on- (whence also Sanskrit takṣan-, tákṣā "carpenter," Avestan tašan-, tašā "builder, creator"), n-stem derivative from a verbal base *tetḱ- "fashion, produce," whence Sanskrit tákṣati "(s/he) fashions, builds from wood," Avestan tāšt "(s/he) forms," Latvian tešu, tèst "to hew," Old Church Slavic tešǫ, tesati "to hew, fell," (with o-grade) Lithuanian tašýti "to hew"

definition: to become filled to overflowing : abound
sentence: The coral reef teemed with thousands of colorful fish swimming in every direction.
origin: Middle English temen, from Old English tīman, tǣman; akin to Old English tēam offspring

definition: a Texan of Hispanic descent —often used before another noun
sentence: Tejano music is a fun style from Texas that blends Mexican sounds with other types of music.

definition: communication from one mind to another by extrasensory means
sentence: In the movie, the two twins were telepathic and could talk to each other without saying a word.

definition: the study of wetlands, such as bogs and marshes.
sentence: If you are interested in swamps and marshes, you might want to study telmatology when you grow up.

definition: earthquake
sentence: We felt a small temblor, or earthquake, that made the dishes in the kitchen rattle for a few seconds.
origin: Spanish, literally, trembling, from temblar to tremble, from Medieval Latin tremulare

definition: of, relating to, or resembling a tempest : turbulent, stormy
sentence: The weather became tempestuous, with very strong winds and heavy rain blowing against the windows.
origin: Middle English tempestuous, Latinization of tempestous, borrowed from Anglo-French, re-formation of Late Latin tempestuōsus, from tempestu-, probably extracted from Latin tempestūt-, tempestūs, archaic variant of tempestāt-, tempestās "stretch of time, season, weather, " + -ōsus

definition: seafood or vegetables dipped in batter and fried in deep fat
sentence: For dinner, we had shrimp tempura, which is light and crispy because it is fried in a special batter.

definition: aggressively persistent in maintaining, adhering to, or seeking something valued or desired
sentence: The little puppy held on tenaciously to his favorite toy and wouldn't let anyone take it.
origin: Latin tenāc-, tenāx "holding fast, clinging, persistent" (from tenēre "to hold, occupy, possess" + -āc-, deverbal suffix denoting habitual or successful performance) +  ,

definition: tenement house
sentence: In the history book, we saw photos of people living in large tenement buildings in the city long ago.
origin: Middle English, "the holding of property, the property so held, building, dwelling," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin tenementum, tenimentum, teneamentum, from Latin tenēre "to hold, occupy, possess" + -mentum

definition: capable of tension : ductile
sentence: The bridge was made of materials with high tensile strength so it wouldn't break when heavy trucks drove over it.
origin: borrowed from New Latin tensilis, from Latin tendere "to extend outward, stretch" + -tilis "subject to, susceptible to (the action of the verb)"

definition: any of various elongated flexible usually tactile or prehensile processes borne by invertebrate animals chiefly on the head or about the mouth

origin: borrowed from New Latin tentāculum, from Latin temptāre, tentāre "to feel, test, examine" + -culum, suffix of instrument (going back to Indo-European *-tlom)

definition: in full dress
sentence: The invitation said the tenue for the party was casual, so I just wore my favorite t-shirt.

definition: the act, right, manner, or term of holding something (such as a landed property, a position, or an office); especially : a status granted after a trial period to a teacher that gives protection from summary dismissal
sentence: The lawyer explained the tenurial rules about who was allowed to use the land for their farm.
origin: Middle English, "possession of land under obligation to a superior, the land so held," borrowed from Anglo-French tenure, teneure, going back to Gallo-Romance *tenitūra "act of possessing," from Latin ten-, base of tenēre "to hold, possess" + -it-, generalized from past participles ending in -itus + -ūra

definition: moderately warm : lukewarm
sentence: The tepidity of the water meant it wasn't hot or cold, but just right for a quick bath.
origin: Middle English teped, from Latin tepidus, from tepēre to be moderately warm; akin to Sanskrit tapati it heats, Old Irish tess heat

definition: a 300th anniversary or its celebration
sentence: Our town had a huge celebration for its tercentenary, which marks its three-hundredth birthday.

definition: either end of a transportation line or travel route; also : the station, town, or city at such a place : terminal
sentence: The bus station is the terminus of the route, where all the passengers have to get off.

definition: a glazed or unglazed fired clay used especially for statuettes and vases and architectural purposes (as for roofing, facing, and relief ornamentation); also : something made of this material
sentence: My mom planted some bright red flowers in a large terra-cotta pot made of baked clay.
origin: Italian terra cotta, literally, baked earth

definition: an inhabitant of the Earth; of or relating to the planet Earth.
sentence: In science fiction stories, a Terran is a person who comes from the planet Earth.

definition: a usually transparent enclosure for keeping or raising plants or usually small animals (such as turtles) indoors
sentence: We built a small terrarium in a glass jar with moss and tiny plants to keep on our desk.
origin: New Latin, from Latin terra + -arium (as in vivarium)

definition: of third rank, importance, or value
sentence: The tertiary colors, like red-orange or blue-green, are made by mixing a primary color with a secondary color.
origin: Latin tertiarius of or containing a third, from tertius third

definition: an insect having four wings.
sentence: A dragonfly is a tetrapteran insect because it has four wings that it uses to fly very fast.

definition: country (a kingdom) in southeastern Asia on the Gulf of Thailand and the Andaman Sea; capital Bangkok area 198,117 square miles (513,120 square kilometers), population 68,616,000
sentence: Thailand is a country in Southeast Asia that is famous for its beautiful beaches and temples.

definition: a specialist in theology
sentence: A theologian is a person who spends their life studying and talking about religious beliefs.

definition: a battle or war among the gods.
sentence: In the old legends, a theomachy was a giant battle between the different gods.

definition: a formula, proposition, or statement in mathematics or logic deduced or to be deduced from other formulas or propositions
sentence: In math class, we used a theorem to prove that the three angles of a triangle always add up to 180 degrees.
origin: Late Latin theorema, from Greek theōrēma, from theōrein to look at, from theōros spectator, from thea act of seeing

definition: teaching about God and the world based on mystical insight
sentence: Theosophy is the study of different ideas about how the world and spirits are connected.
origin: Medieval Latin theosophia, from Late Greek, from Greek the- + sophia wisdom

definition: the science or practice of veterinary medicine.
sentence: If you want to be a doctor for animals, you would study theriatrics to learn how to help them.

definition: bred from the best blood through a long line : purebred
sentence: A thoroughbred is a special type of horse that is famous for being able to run very fast in races.

definition: of, relating to, resembling, or characteristic of Thraso : bragging, boastful
sentence: The giant had a thrasonical way of talking, always boasting that he was the strongest in the land.
origin: Latin Thrason-, Thraso Thraso, braggart soldier in the comedy Eunuchus by Terence

definition: a star in the constellation Draco that was the pole star in ancient times.
sentence: A long time ago, Thuban was the star that people looked at to find north instead of the North Star.

definition: crosswise
sentence: The sailor placed the wooden board thwartwise across the boat to make a seat.

definition: any of a genus (Thymus) of Eurasian mints with small pungent aromatic leaves; especially : a Mediterranean garden herb (T. vulgaris)
sentence: My mom added a little bit of thyme to the chicken to make it smell and taste like fresh herbs.
origin: Middle English time, thyme, borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin thymum, borrowed from Greek thýmon "the plants Thymus capitatus or Satureja thymbra," perhaps of pre-Greek substratal origin

definition: a sheer silk gauze formerly used for clothing and trimmings
sentence: The doll's dress was made of tiffany, which is a very thin and see-through type of silk.
origin: perhaps from obsolete French tiphanie Epiphany, from Late Latin theophania, from Late Greek, ultimately from Greek theos god + phainein to show

definition: a light midday meal : luncheon
sentence: In some countries, people call their light afternoon lunch or snack a tiffin.
origin: probably alteration of tiffing, gerund of obsolete English tiff to eat between meals

definition: hollywood
sentence: Tinseltown is a nickname for Hollywood, where all the famous movies are made.

definition: of a brownish-orange color
sentence: My friend has beautiful titian hair that looks brownish-orange in the sunlight.

definition: a method or process of determining the concentration of a dissolved substance in terms of the smallest amount of reagent of known concentration required to bring about a given effect in reaction with a known volume of the test solution
sentence: In the science lab, we used titration to find out exactly how much of a liquid was needed to change the color of the water.

definition: playful or foolish behavior
sentence: The teacher told the students to stop their tomfoolery and focus on their spelling practice.

definition: the cutting edge of a bird's beak.
sentence: The tomium is the sharp cutting edge of a bird's beak that helps it eat its food.

definition: utter foolishness or nonsense
sentence: When my brother said he saw a purple dragon in the yard, I told him that was just a load of tommyrot.
origin: English dialect tommy fool + English rot

definition: a method of producing a three-dimensional image of the internal structures of a solid object (such as the human body or the earth) by the observation and recording of the differences in the effects on the passage of waves of energy impinging on those structures
sentence: The doctor used tomography to take a special picture that shows different layers of the inside of the body.
origin: Greek tomos section + International Scientific Vocabulary -graphy

definition: a rear seating compartment of an automobile; also : the entire seating compartment
sentence: My dad put a tonneau cover over the back of his truck to keep his tools dry during the rain.
origin: French, literally, tun, from Old French tonel

definition: a pom-pom or tassel on a Scotch bonnet or beret.
sentence: My winter hat has a fuzzy red toorie on the very top that looks like a pom-pom.

definition: of, relating to, or being a part next above the topmast and below the royal mast
sentence: The sailors climbed high up the mast to reach the topgallant sail and catch the wind.

definition: a plant shaped by topiary art
sentence: The garden had a topiary shaped like a giant elephant made out of trimmed green bushes.

definition: very superior in air or attitude
sentence: The toploftical butler acted like he was far more important than anyone else in the house.
origin: probably from the phrase top loft

definition: of or relating to toponyms or toponymy
sentence: A toponymic study helps us understand how cities and rivers got their specific names.

definition: the twisting or wrenching of a body by the exertion of forces tending to turn one end or part about a longitudinal axis while the other is held fast or turned in the opposite direction; also : the state of being twisted
sentence: Torsion happens when you twist an object, like when you wring out a wet towel.
origin: Late Latin torsion-, torsio torment, alteration of Latin tortio, from torquēre to twist

definition: a North Atlantic food fish of the cod family.
sentence: A torsk is a large fish found in the cold waters of the ocean that is related to the cod.

definition: sheer nonsense : bosh
sentence: The story about the moon being made of cheese is nothing but a bunch of tosh.

definition: as often as something happens; repeatedly.
sentence: The rule means that toties quoties, or as often as the situation happens, you must wash your hands.

definition: a pathological condition caused by the action of a poison or toxin
sentence: Toxicosis is a sickness that happens when a person or animal eats something poisonous.

definition: capable of being easily led, taught, or controlled : docile
sentence: The dog was praised for his tractability because he was very easy to train and followed every command.
origin: Latin tractabilis, from tractare to handle, treat

definition: a caterer or a person who provides meals for customers.
sentence: The traiteur prepared all the delicious food and delivered it to the house for the big party.

definition: a cold wind from the north or northeast in the Mediterranean.
sentence: The tramontana is a cold, dry wind that blows from the mountains toward the sea.

definition: to rise above or go beyond the limits of
